column3: 11:42	"    Not all capital gains are tax free in CH. Only ""private capitals gains"" are tax free. Business/professional capital gains are treated as investment income and  taxable for income tax purposes. The distinction is sometimes not so easy but there are a number of indications used to classify capital gains as private capital gains (tax free status) or investment income (taxable). For example capital gains arising from trading in large amounts
column4: use of borrowed funds in trading
column5: etc. would lead to a taxable investment income treatment.

column1: Dividend withholding tax is 35% in CH. This withholding tax has two functions:
- Is final taxation of non-resident recipients (not unusual
column2: almost all countries impose WHT on non-resident recipients
column3: for example
column4: dividend WHT in US and Australia is both 30%)

column1: - Prevent tax evasion by Swiss taxpayer. This means Swiss taxpayers if duly declare it for their own income tax purposes can get a full refund or receive full tax credit for this WHT.
So business capital gains and dividends are actually taxed the same...

Hello

I see a lot of post here regarding people leaving CH and transferring 2nd pillar contributions out of country. However very little on keeping funds in CH during period without a Swiss employer / fund.

I worked for a Swiss employer for about 5 years and built a reasonable 2nd pillar pot. When I left this job 14 months ago I moved the funds into a Post Finance ""Compte Libre"" (Freizügigkeitskonto) account.
This was meant to be a temporary place to park money
column2: until taking another job when the funds would move to new employer. It originally paid 0.5% (hardly great) but has reduced to 0.2% today. The only upside is no fees or really risk to capital.

column1: However my situation today is that I now work for a UK employer
column2: spend 3 days week in London
column3: 2 days working from home. I pay tax in UK
column4: with CH declaration at end of year. My family continue to live in CH
column5: my wife works these and we still own home.

column1: Long term plan is still to find suitable employment in CH again but that might be at least another 12 - 24 months.

In meantime I'm trying to figure out a better thing to do with the 2nd pillar contributions I have in CH. Obviously there is all the risk / return questions - as getting anything better implies accepting some risk on the capital. Additionally it might be only in the fund for a relatively short period before moved out again to future employer (unless I decide to keep separate and start another one).
I'm trying to find a good site / broker which can give me some guidance. So far a few I turned up were:
Wondered if anyone else out there has faced similar issues (possibly due to being self employed) and has some suggestions?
Many thanks
Richard

Well I would consider I'd pay less tax after moving abroad. Difference coming from treating the property as a side income at the top of your tax progression
column2: reasoning is that you have your main income from the job either way
column3: and it was your conscious choice to keep the money invested in the property rather than in e.g. capital-gains-tax-free stocks. A rough calculation to demonstrate:

column1: Assumptions: taxable in city of Zürich
column2: single
column3: 1M wealth
column4: 200K taxable income from main occupation
column5: 20K taxable income from property (from rent or Eigenmietwert minus deductions).

column1: Case 1. You live in Zurich. Taxes for 220K income: 61408 Fr
column2: or 27.9%. But if you didn't have the property
column3: you'd pay only 53512 Fr for 200K. Hence you're paying 7896 Fr taxes for your property
column4: which gives 7896/20K = 39.5% rate.

column1: Case 2. You moved abroad
column2: kept property. Taxable income base in Switzerland is still 220K
column3: and the rate is still 27.9%. BUT: the actual income on which tax is due in ZH is only 20K
column4: you'll pay only 5580 Fr in taxes on it - 27.9% rate.

column1: Actually
column2: as your main income abroad probably would not remain constant
column3: but drop
column4: you'll pay even less... But then there's the question of how your new coutnry is going to treat your swiss income.

column2: 13:43	"    I am not quite sure what you are getting at here
column3: other than a way to convert bonds into cash legitimately. You also need to be careful what you are saying about the restrictions on BVG accounts.

column1: In practice a Freizugigkeitskonto is simply an investment account in which you can place cash from the funds of your pension scheme when you are either not working
column2: have changed jobs or are leaving the country. Many banks and insurance companies offer this type of account and additionally pay a fixed interest of 1.5% either now or at the next quarter end. This might not seem an attractive growth rate so it is possible again with practically every company offering these accounts to switch to a Freizugigkeits depot account. With this type of account it is possible to invest in a range of BVG type funds which offer a (usually) better rate of return. As an example long term bonds over 25 years offering 4% are not unusual and this provides a ""win"" of 2.5% over the standard offerings.

column1: Note here that for the OP it is necessary to ascertain what the motivations are and what can be done with the money in the BVG account. Is this all mandatory BVG or is there additional monies in there? All money that is not mandatory can be cashed in on leaving Switzerland
column2: and this is actually more tax efficient than leaving it in for the reason that monies paid out of the BVG in the form of pension are subject to tax at the normal rate whereas capital payments are taxed at 40% of the normal rate...

It could be due to the difference between booking date and valuta date. Generally speaking Valuta defines availability of the money and when interest starts to accrue whereas booking date defines when the money shows in the account balance. Differences between the two are probably the reason for what roegner describes above.
Valuta cutoff happens between 15:00 and 17:00 these days. Ignoring the intricacies of payments between 3pm and 5pm to keep it simple
column2: any payments that are entered before 3pm get valuta ""today"" whereas those after 5pm get valuta ""tomorrow"" (which can be multiple calendar days away
column3: for instance payments entered before holidays or on Friday evening). So if the new credit was sent after 5pm yesterday
column4: it may not be available before tomorrow (or after 5pm today
column5: i.e. after the valuta cutoff).

column1: The difference between online and ATM may be because ATM uses cash which must be booked immediately whereas online access can be restricted to ""not earlier than valuta""
column2: assuming the full balance is available online to begin with.

column1: Since banks define themselves how they react in these cases and/or what kind of transactions they allow
column2: it may well be that person A (who uses bank xx) never has a problem such as OP whereas person B (who uses bank yy) always has it with respect to
column3: say
column4: salary payments.

column4: the opposition will be or not excluded. Unfortunately
column5: it is quite a technical thing

column7: more like court hearing after which the judge decides based on the documents what is the probability that you owe something. And then

column11: not necesserily a lawyer

This is a very interesting topic and Im pretty surprised that not many more have join in on this thread. Just for my own understanding
column2: is AHV = AVS = 1st pillar?

column1: Anyway
column2: my enrolled agent has been including my 1st pillar contributions
column3: my 2nd pillar contributions
column4: my employers 2nd pillar contributions
column5: my 3rd pillar contributions and the interest gained in the 3rd pillar account as income on my 1040. Now if you take a look at the PDF file that Mullhollander linked to they suggest that the same except for the interests gained in the 3rd pillar account.

column1: What confuses me is what the US will finally count as income when I retire. To be precise Im a dual citizen and have no current plans in renouncing my US citizenship. Mullhollander's PDF suggests that the 1st pillar distribution is not taxed. Why is that? What about the contribution my employer made to the 1st pillar (1st pillar contributions are split 50/50 between employee and employer). The 2nd pillar I can pretty much comprehend
column2: take a look at IRS worksheet A in IRS Publication 575. The 3rd pillar I will not include when it is paid out because Ive been including the contributions and interests gained and therefore it is just a normal account as long as the IRS is concerned.

column1: Lets get back to the 1st pillar. Why are the distributions not taxed when I retire? Where can I find information from the IRS where this fact is clearly stated?
Ive downloaded the US/CH tax treaty

and If I my understanding of the English language does not fail me my impression is that being a US citizen the US will tax my 1st pillar distribution due to the fact that Im a US citizen! The savings clause in Article 1 of the treaty states this in more or less understandable legal English. Not many provisions in the treaty are allowed if you are a US citizen.
To sum up the whole situation it is my understanding that according Articles 1 and 23 in the US/CH tax treaty and being a US citizen the US will fully tax my 1st pillar distribution
column2: but the Swiss will only tax 66% of (the 1st pillar distribution minus the tax paid to the US on this distribution). Now if this is true
column3: why should I be including my 1st pillar contributions as taxable income on my 1040? Binary options are a zero sum game:
What one side wins the other side of the trade loses.
Thus you need to be better than the other side in order to have a chance to make money: You first need to make up for bid/ask spread
column2: trading costs and such silly stuff as the broker taking a bite out of your winning trades. If the broker takes 16% of your winnings (not your payouts
column3: but of your gross profit on the trade) and you usually buy at 50 cents on the potential dollar payout
column4: you need to win about 60% of your bets just to break even (ignoring bid/ask spread and additional costs).

583	Financebankingtaxation	Debt issues (( confused ))	Mischka	2179	41	Location: Canada // Switzerland	01.03.2016
@Mischka
Here is a strategy I have seen work
column2: several times
column3: with people who – for whatever reason – got themselves into debt.  And by this method
column4: they got themselves fully out of debt
column5: too. Yay!

column1: 1.	Do whatever it takes to stand up strong and admit
column2: to yourself and to the creditor
column3: that you do
column4: in fact
column5: owe the money
column6: and that you are
column7: really truly
column8: going to do whatever you can to pay off the debt.

column1: This is partly a question of one’s inner attitude
column2: and partly a paperwork step.

column1: Write to the creditor to say
a)	Yes
column2: I admit that I owe you the money

column1: b)	I cannot pay it all now
c)	I would like to pay
column2: immediately
column3: the sum of Fr.

column1: OR better still:
I have already transferred into your account
column2: today
column3: the sum of Fr.
column4: in partial payment of the debt

column1: d)	I am trying to re-plan my budget and will contact you again soon.  In the meantime
column2: please do not proceed further with the process of debt collection (Betreibung) because I really am trying to pay the money I owe to you.

column1: Do not try to do this by phone
column2: in a personal visit to the office
column3: or by email.

column1: Send this letter signed
column2: and in an envelope
column3: with a stamp.

column1: Beforehand
column2: photocopy or scan it.

column1: If you do
column2: in fact
column3: have an email address of the creditor
column4: then you could
column5: after posting the letter
column6: send a mail
column7: with the scan as an attachment.

column1: 2.	Actually really
column2: truly re-plan your budget.

column1: Spending:
Think long and hard about every single cent that leaves your pocket
column2: and which types of spending you could radically stop or dramatically reduce
column3: permanently or only temporarily until you have managed to pay off your debt.

column1: Income:
Think long and hard about whether there is any way you could legally increase your income.  This
column2: too
column3: perhaps even only for a while
column4: to earn the money to pay off the debt.

column1: 3.	Within a week or maximum 10 days of your first letter to the creditor (or IMMEDIATELY if the creditor happens to reply your first letter)
column2: write a second one.

column1: a)	On DATE-1 I wrote to you to explain that I am trying to find ways to pay my debt to you
column2: and on DATE-1 I transferred Fr. AMOUNT as partial payment of the debt.

column1: b)	Today (DATE-2) I transferred a further Fr. AMOUNT to you.
c)	I have now re-planned my budget and am in a position to offer to pay as follows:
On DATE-1 	Fr. AMOUNT	(first payment made)
On DATE-2		Fr. AMOUNT	(second payment made)
On DATE	Fr. AMOUNT
On DATE	Fr. AMOUNT
On DATE	Fr. AMOUNT
On Date	Fr. FINAL AMOUNT
d)	Would you please confirm that
column2: by making all these payments
column3: I will have paid off the debt in full?

column1: Like the first
column2: send this letter in an envelope
column3: with a scan as an attachment to a mail.

column1: In general
column2: in Switzerland
column3: registered letters are very important.  Without the registration
column4: there is no proof that the letter was
column5: in fact
column6: sent.  Unfortunately
column7: they cost a Fr. 6 additional fee at the Post Office
column8: which might be better used to pay off another Fr. 6 of the debt.  One way to get around this is to physically deliver the letter oneself.  Not necessarily to the official concerned
column9: but to the reception desk.  Take along a copy of the letter
column10: and ask that the receptionist stamp and sign it as “received on DATE”.

column1: Since your partner is working
column2: and you are not
column3: it would probably be a whole lot less trouble for you both if your partner simply paid your Fr. 500 debt immediately.

column1: Some couples run their purse as a joint pool of earnings and expenses.
Others regard each person
column2: at least financially
column3: as separate from the other.  If you and your partner have the latter system
column4: then you might consider setting up such a repayment schedule towards your partner.  Perhaps you could pay the amounts out of your pocket-money by going without some small treats
column5: or perhaps you could work for your partner doing more of the errands or housework than are usually your “job” at home
column6: or by helping someone your partner would like helped (clean the stairs for Granny
column7: wash Dad’s car
column8: help Bob's daughter with her English homework).

column1: If you choose this route
column2: then I suggest you both put in writing exactly what your agreement is
column3: and by when (in which increments) you will have done what you have to do so that the Fr. 500 has been “worked off” and you and your partner both feel the matter has been dealt with fairly
column4: and then closed
column5: so you don’t spend the rest of your lives with this episode hanging over you as a negative memory in your relationship
column6: but rather as a time when you each proved yourselves to the other.  I've seen it done
column7: and things were much
column8: much better afterwards.  Take courage and good luck!

column1: Cross-border insolvency is a very tricky subject. The EU itself has sought to normalize the execution of various national laws in other EU country jurisdictions. Here's a link:

column1: As a general rule
column2: all adults must pay tax on all their earnings. Married couples pay tax together.

column1: All adults must also pay social security contributions (although there are some exceptions for very young people and for old-age pensioners).
All employers must insure their employees for accidents that happen at work.  And for anyone employed for 8 or more hours per week
column2: the employer must also buy insurance for accidents that happen outside of the workplace.

column1: This is a special status.  One cannot avoid the rules applying to the employer/employee contractual obligations merely by saying that the employee is ""self-employed"".  Anyone who wants to hold the status ""self-employed"" must apply to the AHV Office
column2: and supply iformation about how the money is earned (how many clients
column3: for example) and the AHV will then say ""yes"" or ""no"".

column1: Doing casual work and not registering anywhere and not getting the right insurance payments and not paying tax on the earnings.... is quite simply illegal.  And regarded as very serious.
I suggest you and your friend make very sure that you fulfil the law.

column1: 752	Financebankingtaxation	How to declare UK apartments on Swiss tax return	Slayer	1012	2	Location: Zurich	05.12.2015
I have a holiday house in Spain and co-own a house in Germany.
I asked the Zürich tax office what to do
column2: and they said
column3: I should write a letter saying (and including the exact words) ""nach bestem wissen und gewissen"" in which I should state what I believe to be the fair value providing some backing up for my guesstimate.

column1: For the German property I used the purchase price
column2: which I do to the best of my knowledge still believe to be the fair value. I specifically state this in my letter.

column1: For the Spanish property I also pay property tax to the commune in Spain and I show the bill for that to the Swiss tax authorities (albeit the previous year's one as they don't normally send out bills until the following October) and the Zürich tax office accepts the Spanish value estimate as fair.
All I do every year is retrieve that letter on my computer
column2: update the date
column3: look up the exchange rate for 1st January and re-adjust any conversions
column4: print it out
column5: and stick those values onto my tax form and send in the letter (signed) with the tax form.

column1: So far they've never quibbled over my approach
"	Posts: 98	Join Date: Sep 2012	Junior Member	Groaned at 4 Times in 2 Posts	Thanked 13 Times in 13 Posts	no particular reputation at present
753	Financebankingtaxation	How to declare UK ISAs on Swiss Tax Return	Slayer	1547	14	Location: Zurich	01.12.2015
You should put UK savings interest as a gross amount in the DA-1 and claim to offset the UK tax paid against the Swiss tax which will be levied (on the gross amount.)
My understanding is that ""tax credits"" in the UK are not recognised by the Swiss as tax paid by you therefore effectively there is no double-tax agreement.  In theory
column2: for non-ISAs you should declare the dividend amount net of the tax credit and make no claim for tax paid in the UK.  You could try to reclaim the tax credits on the DA-1 if you think the Swiss tax people might buy it.   I'm not sure how it would work if you've paid higher rate supplemental tax on the dividends. Dividends in the UK to non-residents shouldn't attract this tax
column3: unless you've asked to be taxed as a UK resident.  If for ISAs you actually receive the tax credit as part of the dividend
column4: then you would need to declare the gross amount.  I.e. in both cases you declare how much was actually received.

Ok thanks very good to know. Fortunately my positions are not overly sizeable.

I guess it would be in my best interest to hold all my profitable positions until I return to Canada (well at least over £11K). Canada deems you to have acquired your assets on the day you become a resident. Which makes sense as they deem you to have sold and realized all assets on the day you become a non resident.
When a taxpayer becomes a resident of Canada
column2: he is deemed to have acquired all capital assets
column3: unless specifically excluded
column4: at the fair market value on the date he commences residency.  As such
column5: any unrealized but accrued pre-immigration gains would not be subject to Canadian tax when the asset is sold.  Similarly
column6: when a taxpayer ceases Canadian residence
column7: he is deemed to have sold all of his capital assets
column8: unless specifically excluded
column9: at fair market value and the resulting taxable capital gain
column10: if any
column11: would be included in his last Canadian tax return.  If the individual has not been resident in Canada for more than 60 months
column12: any assets he owned at the time he commenced Canadian residency would be excluded from the departure rules.""

column2: 11:27	"    When this happened to us in Canton Zurich
column3: there was no 'liability' until they issue the first bill (invoice) which has a deadline. Then if you can't pay immediately you have to write a letter (we emailed and they said they would accept an email the first time but in future to always write a proper letter) - stating the payment plan that you would like. They then re-issue the new invoices with the amounts separated into monthly payments
column4: and it's only once these come that you need to start paying.

column1: Because it's a Quellensteuer - tax return - adjustment - extra invoice situation
column2: they don't expect any interim payments 'in advance' and any interest payable is a very small amount as it's not interest on the whole year's tax
column3: just a tiny bit of interest from paying late on the adjustment amount..

I've done extensive searching but haven't been able to find any thread related to my situation but I'm not I'm not the only one.

column2: declared it in the UK in my non-UK-resident tax return
column3: and also left some other money in the company.

column1: Now I have to do Swiss tax declaration.  For the dividend it would seem there's a double taxation agreement in place. In general I assume the 10% tax credit received in the UK also can count as a deduction of tax due on the dividend in Switzerland but I see also such a thing as lump-sum deductions (pauschale Steueranrechnung) and can't work out what this means exactly.  I've also seen things in ""Welcome to Switzerland"" type documents that says dividends from such a company would only be taxed at 60% of the (gross/net?) dividend.  I also see things such as directors fees and ""income derived from services"" and these are not be taxable in Switzerland.  I'm guessing a dividend can't in fact be classed under these?   There must be someone out there who's been through a similar thing?

The second thing is the guy in the payroll company who will prepare my tax return says that I have to declare the value (the amount in the bank) and income (which is almost 0) of my UK limited company as it's counted as me owning shares and these are ""movable assets"". In theory yes I have 100% of the shares in my UK company but is this correct?  If it were a partnership or self-employed then I could understand it but usually in England LTD companies are separate entities.

I'm very convinced that the tax guy in the payroll company has no idea about someone in my situation. He's just said I will have to declare and pay tax on everything and I can't claim any rebate for dividends or other tax paid  in the UK.

The other thing is he says it's ok to submit for the UK financial year Apr-Apr instead of the Swiss one Jan-Dec as I have the tax certificates for this period.  Does anyone else do this?  What then about income in the first quarter of the first year I was here?
Many thanks for reading!
Landers

column1: "	Posts: 110	Join Date: Nov 2009	Member	Groaned at 15 Times in 4 Posts	Thanked 27 Times in 7 Posts	earned some respect
922	Financebankingtaxation	Transferring large sums from Canada?	swisscanmom	7556	52	Location: near Langenthal
Wow
column2: there is a lot of misinformation on this thread.

column1: First
column2: a few hints.  You can use a cheque or bankers draft to bring the money over here
column3: but this is a very expensive and time-consuming process.  Your Swiss bank will charge you handsomely for this service
column4: and they won't credit your account until the funds have cleared.  This can take weeks or even months in some cases.  You won't have any visibility of the exchange rate that you'll get -- you'll get the rate on the day that the money clears.

column1: Summary: your money will get here
column2: eventually
column3: but at a high cost.  Not a great choice.

column1: A   better solution is to use XE.com to transfer the money.  You can do all the paperwork and set up the account now (this takes a few days
column2: so better to get the process started well in advance).  You'll have instant visibility of the exchange rate that you'll get
column3: no additional fees to pay at either end
column4: and a simple domestic Canadian transaction from the point-of-view of your Canadian bank.  The whole process takes about 3 days from initiating the transfer until the money is in your Swiss bank account.

column1: The other advantage of this is that you can first transfer a *small* amount of money to make sure that everything works as intended.  It's a little nerve-wracking to have your entire life savings lost somewhere in the international banking system (I speak from first-hand experience).
XE does nothing all day but move money back-and-forth internationally.  They're specialists at it
column2: and they do it very well.

column1: A final solution would be to leave a signed wire order
column2: without recipient account details
column3: with your bank manager in Canada.  Tell him/her that you'll give them the account details later (they'll probably insist on a fax - it's a very old-world system).  This would also work if your bank manager is willing to take the draft
column4: although this depends on how strong your relationship is with the bank.

column1: If your bank isn't a specialist expat bank (like HSBC)
column2: I actually don't like this option too much.  The banks don't have much experience moving money internationally
column3: and there are too many things that can go wrong.

column1: As I said before
column2: I'd use a specialist broker like XE.  It'll be the quickest
column3: cheapest
column4: easiest way to get your money over here.

column2: how do I get taxed?	bella_suiza	1062	8	Location: Zurich	07.08.2015

column1: If you move between cantons
column2: you are taxed in the canton where you have your official residency on 31/12. If you move within the canton
column3: you are taxed where you have your official residency on 01/01 (at least in the canton of Zurich). So if you move from the canton of Zurich to the canton of Zug on 30/12 you will be taxed in the canton of Zug. If you move from Zurich City to Oerlikon on 02/01 you will be taxed in Zurich City. This assumes that you are either not taxed at source or are above the threshold and file a tax return.

column1: "	Posts: 5	Join Date: Apr 2008	Banned	Groaned at 0 Times in 0 Posts	Thanked 1 Time in 1 Post	no particular reputation at present
941	Financebankingtaxation	My Experience with MidPoint (Int'l Money Transfer)	Curran919	956	0	Location: Effretikon
Midpoint is a P2P money transfer service
column2: very similar to CurrencyFair. I have seen the latter mentioned numerous times on the forum
column3: but was surprised that MidPoint did not show up at all in a search. It is newer
column4: sure
column5: but not only gave me a better deal but also has different currencies available. I believe that when I checked in June 2015
column6: that it was only these two services that would allow me to transfer CAD to CHF.     The Cost

column1: I needed to send about 10000CHF from Canada as seed money when we moved here. There is a minimum charge of 10GBP
column2: but above about 4000CHF
column3: the charge is 0.50% of the transfer value. The exchange rate used is the midpoint rate (compared to XE.com rates)
column4: hence the name. Using sample values
column5: the CurrencyFair and MidPoint prices for the same trasnfer come to within $1. With my bank
column6: the use of a 'buy' exchange rate would have led to about a 1.4% loss in the transfer compared to the midpoint rate. This saved about 90CHF. Note that the exchange rates for a credit card can yield a loss of up to 2.5%.     How It Works

column1: You put an order in for buying X currency A or selling X currency B. Within 24 hours
column2: they will match you with someone (or multiple people) wanting to exchange the other way (this is all behind doors). When you submit your order
column3: you fill in the account details for the recipient account. You get a message when you are matched with someone providing bank details where your sum must be deposited. Note that the sum is calculated from the exchange rate at matching not at ordering. You make a transfer to this bank account with the correct sum
column4: and when your matched person also do this
column5: your money will go to their receiving account and vice versa. You have 72 hours for the money to get to their account or there could be 'penalties' (you don't want to keep your match waiting...)
column6: although it seems they have no way of enforcing these if you never pay. This is because MidPoint themselves have very low liquidity and can normally not put up currency themselves
column7: which is why they are a cheaper service.     Sending from North America

column1: MidPoint has bank accounts in all of the countries they operate in for you to deposit directly into... except for US/Canada. This is also the case for CurrencyFair and is a bit of a pain. You have to deposit the money into a UK bank which has its own associated costs. A wire transfer from your bank should costs $20-50 and should have no hidden 'exchange fees' since you are transfering CAD-CAD or US-US but also [usually] requires you to do this at your bank IN PERSON.     My Experience

I (Canadian) was in Canada and my wife (EU) had just opened up an account with PostFinance. I wanted to try the service out with a small amount since there was so little information on it on the forums (yet a bit of journalism on the web). I arranged to send 1000CAD to her account. For this small amount
column2: the fee was 10GBP which actually came out to 1.5%
column3: more than my bank. When UK markets opened the following day (MidPoint based in UK)
column4: I was matched quickly and taken by surprise that the bank was in the UK. It IS in their FAQ
column5: but they should really also have a warning when transfering from Canada/US. I thought
column6: ""no problem
column7: I can send an international remittance."" This would be through online banking for amounts less than $2500 and charging a $13.50 additional fee to my bank. Not so. International remittances can only be sent in GBP/USD
column8: not CAD. I contact the MidPoint looking for some guidance. They reply within 10 minutes to say that people DO infact transfer money through my bank in Canada
column9: but that if I was going to have trouble
column10: given it was a small amount and my first time
column11: they would cancel the order. I obliged since I was living on an island at the time with no branch for my bank. I phoned my bank the next day and they confirmed that indeed you do have to come into a branch to send money in that manner.

column1: The day before going to Vancouver
column2: I order another transfer
column3: this time for the full 10000CHF. I am quickly matched again and go to a branch the next day for the transfer. Everything runs smoothly and I pay $35 total to send the money with next day deposit
column4: within the 72h. Three days later I am waiting for my wife to receive money when I get an email saying the money hasn't been deposited. With a few emails back and forth
column5: I forward them my receipt of wire transfer. The bank teller had put the mandatory receiver's reference in the sender's reference section. They HAD received the money but didnt automatically know it was from me. After another day
column6: all was fine.

column1: Two MORE days later
column2: Another message comes in explaining that PostFinance had bounced the deposit back. More talking with MidPoint and we found another of my errors in the receiving bank info (confusing field named 'account name' should be 'name of account owner'). Another try and the money is finally available the next evening
column3: about 9 days after first making the order
column4: though this should generally be much less if everything is done correctly the first time.     Conclusion

column1: While the numbers will dictate where the best 'product' is
column2: I had a great opportunity to really put the customer service of MidPoint through its paces and was very impressed. Over a dozen emails sent with two representatives
column3: but whom actually spoke with eachother (and had names!) They were able to easily solve all of my problems and always answered my emails within 5-10 minutes and within 30 minutes of the market opening. With all of the delays
column4: it wasn't worth saving the 90CHF in the end
column5: but it will be next time when I do everything correctly.

column1: I hope someone else can chime in with their experience or comparison with other services if anyone has actually ever used MidPoint on here.

column1: I went into Jelmoli about 7.50pm on 31st July (about 10 minutes before they were due to close for the Swiss national holiday)
column2: filled out the application form and gave them photocopies of my passport and work permit (""Bewilligung""). Two weeks later I started phoning Bonuscard (the card supplier behind Jelmoli - literally as well as figuratively!) to check the status of my application
column3: and was told that they had no record of my application. Even though Bonuscard's offices are literally 100m from the Jelmoli store in the centre of Zürich
column4: it appears that my application never made it across.

column1: I then filled out a new application form off the internet at   (site only in German or French - go into the store and get help filling out the form if you don't speak either)
column2: went to Bonuscard's offices at 18 St. Annagasse in the centre of Zürich
column3: gave them

column1: * my signed and completed application form
* a photocopy of my passport
* a photocopy of my work permit (only an L
column2: due to intial 6-month contract)

column1: * a photocopy of my contract with my agency
* a photocopy of my most recent payslip
* a photocopy of my contract on my flat
* a photocopy of my broadband contract
to demonstrate as much as possible that I not only had a good job
column2: but had both an entitlement to be here and a commitment to staying here
column3: and yesterday I got a shiny new gold Jelmoli Visa card with a 5000F credit limit
column4: no annual fee as long as I spend more than 300F per year and no requirement to put up funds to the value of the credit limit of the card
column5: which had been the stumbling block to applying for a credit card of the bank for which I work. 5000/10000F are 2 months / 4 months mortgage repayments on my UK mortgage
column6: and that's much more important to me!

column1: So anyway
column2: that's what worked for me
column3: and now I am no longer paying foreign exchange charges and commission for every transaction that I make in CH on my UK credit card
column4: only to get stung again when sending Francs back to the UK to pay off the card at the end of the month.

column1: If I had my startup time again I would apply for a Cornercard Reload card straight away to minimise the foreign exchange and commission charges
column2: then for a Jelmoli Visa card once I had got my Bewilligung and then probably cancel the Cornercard Reload card at the end of the first year.

column2: 19:37	"    A person's nationality is totally irrelevant for a Betreibung.

column1: Anybody can be served with a Betreibung in Switzerland
column2: however
column3: I believe in order for this to actually be served
column4: the person has to be resident in Switzerland at the exact time the Betreibungsamt is asked to serve it
column5: for at that moment in time the Betreibungsamt will verify with the Einwohnerkontrolle of the Gemeinde where the alleged debtor has an address whether the person is currently a resident and at what address exactly.

column1: If the person is not resident in Switzerland at that moment in time (has notified departure and has physically departed or was never a resident in the first place)
column2: I don't see how the Betreibung can be even be created
column3: let alone served.

column1: I doubt that a Betreibung can be served to someone who is resident in another country.
A Betreibung must not be served by ordinary post (although I do know of one case where it was)
column2: nor must it be delivered by registered letter. In theory it should be delivered exclusively in person. So it wouldn't be sent on to you through the post to your country.

column1: A Betreibung ought not to have any consequences for other countries such as in the EU
column2: as the process concerns wholly persons residing in Switzerland.

column1: If the person has already been served with a Betreibung and then departs
column2: this is a different matter
column3: as the procedure is underway
column4: but whether the procedure can then continue without you being present I am not sure.

column2: 20:33	"    I would like to be helpful as I work on the three countries' tax issues (and some other countries too) and in fact pay tax to the three countries. But I do not (i.e. not ever) accept paying clients from the Internet. So what I can give you is general advice.

column1: TurboTax (you may need the business edition) should be sufficient to deal with your US tax issues. It is a very clever program. But you will need to learn how Switzerland
column2: the UK and the USA define certain matters differently. If you come from a US community property state you are halfway there as in CH you need to file joint returns. You can in the USA but you do not say whether you are married so this may be irrelevant. (The UK
column3: England & Wales anyway
column4: have an arcane rule on recognition of community property when that has been established in another country
column5: the technical name is immutability whereas the US rule (which you probably know but don't know the name of) is partial mutability.)

column1: For CH either your taxes will be a matter of your employer (since you are not a CH citizen as I understand it you can't file a full tax return as an option
column2: and I am assuming you don't have investment interests in CH that would pre-empt that rule).

column1: For the UK
column2: online form SA-106 is fairly straightforward. But unless you are dual-resident (UK/CH for example) or have rental property in the UK
column3: it isn't obvious that you will need to file there after the year you leave. On the other hand you might want to contrive voluntary Class 2 NICs (if you qualify or can) to get a state pension. And you certainly should contrive 10 years (40 quarters) of Social Security contributions to qualify for Medicare since Part A is then free & gratis.

column1: Above all
column2: don't panic. While PFIC and FATCA and all the rest are nasty & evil
column3: don't let the nastiness get you down. British tax returns SA-100 are easy (apparently they are going to be abolished but that's another story). You might need a ""mandataire"" in Switzerland. But rely on TurboTax and you should be OK. Just remember to check the box at the foot of Sched B Form 1040 (answer the question about foreign bank accounts) and if you have more than $10
column4: 000 abroad
column5: do FinCEN 114 (formerly FBAR).

column1: It's PFIC (Google it) that is the trap for the unwary. And I understand Swiss pensions don't have the exemption that the UK-US tax treaty offers. But then your lovely Congress keeps enacting statutory overrides to tax treaties: AMT and the 3.8% Obamacare investment tax are just two of them...
Good luck. I don't check this forum often but you can try to send a PM and maybe I'll figure out how to read it...

column2: 21:15	"    Every property has a ""theoretical"" rental value (Eigenmietwert in german) - you are taxed on this value.

column1: If the property is rented out the pro-rata eigenmietwert + the actual rental is the amount you are taxed on.

You can then deduct mortgage interest and upto a maxiumum of 20% of the total rental value (without receipts) as deductions. A greater level of deductions can be made but this needs individual receipts - and is often only done when you are make a major renovation.
In your case they take the actual rent + 11/12 of the eigenmietwert. Even if you are only there for 1 month a year.
Tax authorities consider a property should be used - either lived in or rented out.

column2: you can't send CHF payments via SEPA
column3: as SEPA payment is specific to EUR payments only and within Europe. However
column4: you can send EUR payments from Switzerland as a SEPA payment to another EU country as Switzerland is signed up to this Payment Directive although it's not in EU.

column1: All international transfers are done via SWIFT but SEPA payment instructions are sent within the SWIFT messaging instruction.

column2: USD transfers will be differently designed container.

1084	Financebankingtaxation	Employer BVG %	Dack Rambo	1963	17	Location: Switzerland	07.05.2015
The situation as of 1.1.2015:
i) maximum AHV payment (old age insurcane) for singles is 28'200.-
ii) Koordinationsabzug is 7/8 that of the AHV maximum => 28200 * 7/8 = 24'675.-
iii)  point 1.7 in your contract. This is called 2nd pillar ""2a""
column2: defined by  BVG
column3: maximum insured salary is 84'600 less 24'675 = 59'925.-

column1: This  salary portion is called ""koordinierter Lohn""(KL). Depending on  the  employees age a certain percentage (increases are laddered) of the  KL  must be paid into 2a
column2: whereby the employer must pay at least as much  as  the employee - thus 50-100% of all payments into 2a are shouldered  by the  employer.

column1: iv)  point 1.8 in your contract. Income above BVG maximum is called  ""überobligatorischer Lohn""
column2: 2nd  pillar ""2b"". I may be wrong
column3: but I  think savings for this part of the  salary are voluntary and fall under  ordinary insurance  laws
column4: this would also mean that the employer is free  to also pay or not.

column1: Note that 84'600 = 3 * 28'200. This is referred to by ""das Dreifache"" in 1.7 as well as by ""300%"" in point 1.8
Your  contract looks ok to me. Some employers (large ones mostly) have a  separate  ""Pensionskassenreglement"" wherein they define details
column2: especially if they provide additional benefits.

column1: The ""Mindestzins"" defined by the Bundesrat covers pillar 2a only.

If you are an independent there is of course no limit. But if you are an employee of a company that pays your contributions to a pension plan
column2: insurance and unemployment then there could be an issue if you work more than a defined limit of hours/week. The reasons:

column1: - you have paid vacation during which you are not supposed to work; vacation is paid by company so that you come back fit again for optimal productivity.
- the more hours/week you work
column2: the higher are the chances that you'll get sick or a work accident; so here the insurances put a pressure on your employer to enforce the limit of working hours/week.

Hi Morphopera!
It is never too late to start investing in a Swiss pension! As a self employed
column2: it's possible that you don't have an occupational pension plan (2nd pillar). But you do have the mandatory first pillar which is AVS/AI and unemployment insurance.

column1: You can still invest in a private pension plan which is the 3rd pillar (although you might not have the 2nd pillar)! Self-employed persons without an occupational pension plan can pay in up to 20 % of their annual earned income
column2: but a maximum of CHF 33'840.

column1: You can also choose between the   one. With the first one
column2: you have tax deductible contributions but you cannot take your savings out any time you like. The second one has fewer tax advantages but there are also less restrictions!

column1: You can have a look on this website that provides useful information and advice about pensions plans and Swiss life in general:
If you need an english speaking advisor
column2: a specialised agency like Creditloan can offer you a free analyse of your financial situation if order to find you a third pillar plan that is adapted to you!

column1: I hope I could help answering your question! I wish you the best with your future plans! Kind regards.

1230	Financebankingtaxation	CH pension payout to a non-US citizen taxed in the US?	jcvidal	1236	5	Location: Zurich	18.02.2015
Disclaimer: I am not a personal income tax expert. However
column2: I am a US taxpayer.

column1: Assuming you move to the US during fiscal year 2015
column2: and we are talking about the 2015 U.S. tax return (which you will file in 2016) - the first thing you need to determine is whether you are a resident or non-resident alien   for the year. Be careful
column3: because the definition of resident alien for immigration purposes (green card) is not the same as the definition of resident alien for tax purposes. For example
column4: you could be a non-resident alien (for example H1-B visa holder) for immigration purposes
column5: but a resident alien for tax purposes.

column1: For tax purposes
column2: you are a resident alien if you meet certain criteria
column3: such as the ""green card test"" and the ""substantial presence test"" for the fiscal year. Assuming you meet those criteria
column4: the tax treatment is the same as if you were a US citizen or green card holder - i.e. your 2015 worldwide income is subject to US income tax.

column1: If you are a non-resident alien for tax purposes (i.e. you do not meet the criteria as above)
column2: you pay US tax on the amount of your effectively connected income for 2015.

column1: The IRS website explains all these cases
column2: criteria
column3: definitions
column4: etc.

column1: Personal advice: aside from reading the IRS website
column2: now is the time to talk to a professional about your situation (not after you have already moved to the US)
column3: and potentially consider the right timing of your move to the US in the 2015 fiscal year vis-a-vis the potential Swiss income that you might have in the fiscal year. I hope this helps a little bit!

- I have a permanent work contract with a Swiss company.

- I have mobile phone contracts.
- I am applying for a credit card (which my bank offered me a while ago but I declined) which I now think will be good for building a credit history if I pay it off in full each month.

I am looking for a new car from a mainstream dealership on what would be described in the UK as a PCP finance agreement. It is one where you get a balloon figure at the end to offset costs and I believe from other posts on the forum that the Swiss call this leasing.
My questions are:
- How easy is it to get finance agreements from mainstream dealerships if you are on a B permit?
- Will the fact I have phone contracts (2) and a prepaid credit card help my credit history (they are in good order) or would I need a proper credit card as well?

Many thanks in advance and best wishes to you all.

column1: For many years I have completed my tax declaration (Tax return) electronically
column2: in Bern & in Fribourg. This year Canton Fribourg have a new system
column3: and I came up against a problem that might affect you in the same way.

column1: When I have completed a form on paper
column2: I have never left a field blank: I always added ""none"" or ""0"" and for years I have continued this habit with online tax forms. It shows you have read the question and either you have ""zero amount"" or the question is irrelevant.

column1: With the new Fribourg declaration I happily put ""none"" or ""0"" everywhere and when I clicked to send it off
column2: the computer said ""NO"" and asked me how many trees I had and how much my temporary staff earned. I retraced my steps and I have come to the conclusion that if I had anything marked in the answer box / field
column3: I was asked for further details.

column1: So I went back and happily deleted everything with ""0"" and the declaration form went off successfully.

column2: 17:11	"    MAximum AHV Loan is for 2007 79560. The ""koordinationabzug"" ie the AHV bit is 23205. Minimum BVG is then paid on the difference. This is described in Art 2
column3: 5+7 of BVG.

column1: To your other question. You have a good year and prepay several years BVG. This goes in your company ""pot"". On Jan 1 of each year it is then paid over to your employees accounts or paid monthly as you wish. Once it is paid into the pot of the accounts it can't be touched. Only you have several years of money paid in and when you liquidate the company you get to collect the pot into your personal pension fund. Simply put once paid in the money can't be taken out and there is no-one else left in the company to pay it to. So you land the jackpot all legitimate and above board. And of course you then have a big fat BVG. All you then need to do is wait five years and retire. Simple really... Of course you do need to get the employees etc first.
The five year wait is a precaution I would take but technically it is not necessary. As soon as you are 58 you put your feet up take capital and bobs your uncle so to speak.
Any more questions about second pillars?

My guess is your only option is to stay tax resident in Germany. The link I sent you explains the procedure: you declare to the German finanzamt that you work in CH for 3 months and your income here. They will give you a bill for prepayment of your taxes and a document that you should send to your CH employer (called 'Ansässigkeitsbescheinigung' or 'Vordruck Gre1') . Based on this document your employer will correct your tax at source to tariff M/N (both 4.5% so it will not matter if your wife is employed or not). At the end of the year you file your taxes in Germany where among other deductions you can deduct the extra costs you made for working in CH
column2: like the second household
column3: and the 4.5% tax you prepaid as tax-at-source in CH. Do contact your German tax consultant as he might save you more money than you have to pay him in your not-so-straightforward situation. Good luck!

column1: now
column2: what is exactly an asset and what is liability?

column1: It is easy to say

column3: which are given
column4: are investments in real estate
column5: backed with credits. So
column6: there was a man
column7: who had 10K
column8: he wanted to buy himself a car
column9: but he read a smart book and instead of buying a car he bought a house with 10K of downpayment and 90K credit
column10: he rented a house
column11: he paid mortgage with a money he received from tenants
column12: than in 5 years the house was worth 200K so he sold it and made 100K out of his 10K. Than he bought a whole building  with his 100K
column13: which he used a downpayment
column15: paid the mortgage using money he got from tenants. After 5 years his building was worth 2M so he sold it - now he had 990K which he made out of his initial 10K.

column1: I believe

The situation used to be that when one married partner was working less than 15 hours per week and earning less than 2000CHF/month they could be taxed according to tarif D (nebenerwerb - supplementary income) which was a flat rate of 10% and the main provider by B. This was the case for me and my husband a few years ago when he worked only a few hours per week. It looks like this changed from the beginning of this year
column2: and now both partners are taxed to C
column3: no matter how low the income of one of them is (you can find the changes for ZH on page 3 of the first letter  ). Obviously this is more disadvantageous the lower that second income is. Totally ridiculous
column4: and maybe it is worth to file a complaint about this change calculating your losses compared to the old situation
column5: and explaining that it discourages you
column6: and most probably many more part-time working spouses from working at all?

column1: Actually
column2: the new tariffs are disadvantageous for all married couples who both work and whose incomes differ
column3: more so the more they differ
column4: as before 2014 the person earning more was taxed to a lower rate than the one earning less (this was the 'wives' tariff C(EF) as obviously everybody knows it is always the woman earning less   ) - we ended up paying about 12% more quellensteuer overall since the beginning of this year because both partners now are taxed according to the same tariff.

1559	Financebankingtaxation	Good Guaranteed returns from Investment.	swagata.manna	1271	3	Location: ZURICH	03.08.2014

I think first and foremost the idea that there is a truly ""guaranteed"" investment needs to be dispelled. A guarantee is only as robust as the institution issuing it. One can choose between different levels of risk. E.g. US government bonds are considered very low risk investments
column2: people sometimes going as far as labeling them `risk-free` in literature (mainly for financial instrument price modeling purposes). Note that US government bonds are guaranteed only as far as the US government promising to pay their obligations. Only recently this promise has been nearly broken (look up the 2013 debt crisis).

column1: Investments where the notional is guaranteed are also not entirely risk free. In case the bank/institution collapses
column2: there is no telling when/if clients get their money back. Governments can decide not to pay their obligations or restructure them such that bond holders have to take a hit.

column1: All this factors into the interest on a ""guaranteed"" investment. Some years ago
column2: one could open a bank account in Cyprus and harvest a nice and cool 6-7% interest rate. This was deemed risk free by many people. They were not investing in anything after all
column3: just opening a bank account. Only last year cyprus went tits up and many people lost a lot of money by simply having their money in a bank.

column1: With that being said
column2: the safest investments by retail standard will not yield more than a 1% a year
column3: if even that. As other posters wrote
column4: one is looking at small fractions of a percent. With sums below 10k
column5: the interest minus account fees will be far below inflation in all likelihood. There is no real point speculating about the options here unless OP wants to park at least a six figure sum since it will not be worth the time spent.

What do you mean by ""confiscation"" here?
If you are referring to depositor protection of up to 100'000 CHF (with nothing above 100'000 being protected unless you bank with a Cantonal bank that provides an unlimited guarantee
column2: which in theory sounds great but in practice may be questionable)
column3: this is not really new and has been around since 2005. The scheme is required under Federal law and pushes all Swiss banks to effectively bail out the troubled Swiss bank:

column1: Most Swiss Cantonal Banks have an unlimited guarantee on bank liabilities
column2: fully backed by the respective Cantonal government under Cantonal law. BEKB and BCV have no such cantonal guarantees and BCGE has a limited cantonal guarantee which will be fully phased out by 2016. In my view
column3: Cantonal guarantees create an incentive for risky behavior which may push a bank to insolvency and force the canton to bail them out with taxpayer's (read ""depositor's"") money.

column1: If Switzerland were indeed to pass confiscatory measures à la Chypre
column2: the consequences to the Swiss economy (which is in very solid shape compared to the ROW) would be so extreme and the resulting capital flight would literally turn the country insolvent.

column1: The advice I got from a Swiss tax advisor  was against transferring my UK private pension for the following reason :

1. If you want transfer your UK pension overseas it needs to go into a QROPS (qualified registered overseas pension scheme). Schemes like this promise to keep your funds in a bubble that replicates UK pensions environment
column2: eg no withdrawal before 55. This is to ensure that you don't transfer overseas and then withdraw it all straight away for example.

column1: 2. Say your employers (company a) scheme is QROPS
column2: great. But if you change jobs  to another company (company b)  with a pension fund you MUST  transfer your entitlement from company a to company number.

column1: 3. What happens if company b pension fund isn't a QROPS? Well the UK tax man could come after you.
Now if you're close to or over 55 then it isn't such a problem. Also of you're sure you're not moving employers you can take a punt.
Basically beware.

column1: Nearly all your assets outside Switzerland will be included in the calculation of wealth tax
column2: including those held in tax-efficient wrappers (like the 529 college plan).  Typically you need to declare any liquid assets
column3: your house
column4: and your cars.  Jewellery isn't declared
column5: to my knowledge.

column1: I haven't heard about any exemption for a house in a foreign country -- as far as I know
column2: the house is considered when calculating wealth.  You can
column3: of course
column4: deduct the value of any mortgage you have on the house
column5: so you're only paying on the equity in the house.

column1: Unless you're fantastically wealthy
column2: I wouldn't worry too much about the wealth tax.  In my case (with a ""reasonable"" amount of wealth and a salary above the US Foreign Earned Income Exemption level)
column3: my Swiss tax liability was lower than my US tax liability
column4: eg
column5: I ended up owing US taxes in addition to my Swiss taxes.  So regardless of the wealth tax
column6: my overall tax burden was the same.  The only difference the wealth tax made was the size of the cheque I wrote to the Swiss vs. US tax authorities.

1739	Financebankingtaxation	Einzelfirma as a B-Permit holder	ToniT	1602	5	Location: Zug	21.03.2014
You can have your own Einzelfima if you have a B permit.

You will pay income tax at the end of the financial year (so the next year) when you get your income declaration papers from the tax office. When you have an Einzelfirma you declare the income on your personal tax declaration. (I recommend having an accountant to do it all)

Companies here (your big companies) like to use agencies because it makes their life easier. Agencies in CH take a huge commission for doing very little and they minimize their liability by having you be payrolled. If you are pay-rolled and you have a B permit you will pay tax at source. (the agency will deduct the tax from your income and pay it in on your behalf)

Hello
The account limit of 1'000 Chf is the negative amount you can reach at max.  That does not necessarily means the amount you can spend from card per month. Indeed
column2: an example:

column1: - Imagine you have a 0 Chf card balance.
- You use your card for 300 Chf. So you are at -300 Chf balance and thus spend 700 Chf more (as the limit is -1'000 Chf).
- You load your card with 500 Chf. Your new balance is +200 Chf (-300 + 500). That means you can now spend 1'200 chf on your card (you have +200
column2: you can reach -1'000).

column1: It is important to understand that you can load a credit card with more than the amount due and then have the possibility to spend more than the limit given.
Also
column2: for your questions
column3: hard to answer without more informations:

column1: - Did you use your card after or just before paying 600 Chf?
From what I can see
column2: my guess is:

column1: - You had -1'000 Chf Balance on your account number
- You paid 600 Chf
- The total of the card should have been +600 Chf but maybe you used it for around 250 Chf a few day before or after loading it? That means 600 - 250 = 350 Chf.
- That's why you only have a +350 Chf on your card instead of a +600.

To answer your question: I would consider Post Finance (card reader system) or for example ""SMS-TAN"" (Raiffeisenbank / several Kantonalbanken / etc) to be probably ~the safest.
BUT your tan being ""hacked"" is actually not the danger of E-Banking. Having worked for half a year in this area I know that the real danger are Malware
column2: Trojans
column3: Viruses which are on your computer and just ""copy"" your session ( ). So for actual safety the most important thing is that you have an Anti-Virus software installed and use the internet safely. If you really want the safety even against such things then there's only one option I know of:

column1: Multiple banks offer that you can order the sentinel directly from them. For example St. Galler Kantonalbank
column2: Thurgauer Kantonalbank
column3: Basler Kantonalbank and also some private banks as Julius Bär. Best ask in advance if you choose another bank. But the Sentinel can also be used with (practically) any other bank.

column1: I hope this helps.

Oh and one other note: There is no 100% safety. But if something happens there's a huge chance that your bank will cover any loss as it's really bad for their image if it gets public that there was a breach somewhere and a client was robbed.

column2: 12:32	"    Not sure I understand you question... But here goes...

column1: If you look on the statement you will see that there is a line indicating the maximum amount you are allowed to buy in.  This amount will normally amount to the short fall in the obligatory amount (not to be confused with the BVG amount) or perhaps a little more.  So when you buy in
column2: little or none should end up in the extraordinary amount
column3: because it is first applied to the obligatory amount.

column1: Once the obligatory amount is fully ensured there is no possibility to have further funds applied there until such time as a new hole opens up
column2: which normally happens when you receive a pay increase and provided your overall contributions do not exceed the max buy in amount.

column1: What can happen is when a hole does open up in the obligatory amount
column2: there is still to much in the extraordinary amount and so the maximum buy in amount is still zero.  In such cases you are not allowed to top up the obligatory amount from the extraordinary amount.

column2: 11:24	"    Capital gains are not normally taxed for private individuals... unless you count as a (semi-)professional trader for tax purposes.

column1: [-> the capital gains are large enough that they count it as a source of income similar to a full or side job]
You normally have to declare trading activities in your tax declaration.
The relevant tax circular is (in German):
They lay out a number of cumulative conditions under which the tax authorities will for sure NOT consider you taxable:
-Held the securities for longer then 6 months
- Transaction volume over the tax year not greater than 5x value of the held securities at the beginning of the year
- Capital gains less than 50% of your declared income
- No leverage or the interest on leverage lower than the taxable income from dividends
- Derivatives trading limited to hedging
In practise they won't care about the above rules for small amounts
column2: but for large capital gains where the above is not fulfilled they will look into it and decide if you are taxable or not (not fulfilling all the conditions doesn't mean you necessarily have to pay tax
column3: but I would get professional tax advice in such a case...)

column2: Social Security	seekinganswers	1054	0	Location: Renens	30.09.2013

column1: Hello Group
column2: US Expat here

column1: Because I now receive US Social Security payments
column2: income I make here in Switzerland makes part (up to 85%) of my Social Security income taxable in the US.

column1: The Foreign Earned Income Exclusion form (2555EZ) in Part IV says to enter the foreign income ""earned and received""
column2: also to enter it on the 1040
column3: line 7.  What I received is the amount stated in my employment contract.  Even though that amount will be excluded (it is under the Max exclusion)
column4: it still influences the amount of my Soc Sec that I must pay taxes on - there is a long worksheet to calculate the taxable amount (Pub 915)
column5: and it requires foreign earned income to be entered.

column1: The problem is this:  while I received what my contract states
column2: it is technically my net income.  For the salary certification
column3: the employer worked backwards to figure what gross income figure was needed to end up after all the deductions with my contract amount.  I had no clue about this
column4: as they gave me 4 years of salary certifications only a few months ago!

column1: The question:  can I report my contract amount as the foreign income
column2: or must I report this much larger backwardly calculated figure?

column1: When I first came to Switzerland my employer told me there was a tax treaty between US and Switzerland
column2: to protect against double taxation.  So I never even thought about US taxes.  Ignorance is bliss
column3: but the bliss is morphing into pain.

column1: Thanks for looking in.
seekinganswers

column2: 18:33	"      In my experience:

column1: - first you have to find a store that does tax free (not all are obliged to offer it). Then each shop has its own policy on min spend (eg £50 or £100).
- You shop around the store
column2: then take the receipts to their tax-free department in the store (signs in store). You show passport and Swiss permit and fill in the forms.

column1: - At the airport
column2: you (i) must carry the stuff with you through security (ii) follow the signs to HM Revenue and Customs. You show the goods
column3: boarding pass
column4: passport and Swiss permit and they stamp the forms that youhave ""exported the goods"". Note that you must be flying to somewhere outside the EU (eg Switzerland
column5: USA
column6: Japan

column1: - Then it depends on the store policy. MOST stores by far use a company called ""Global blue"" (and the forms you'd have will say global blue on them). In that case you just take the stamped form to the global blue kiosk at the airport
column2: usually next door to the HMRC office. They give you an immediate cash refund
column3: but they take a cut (a %) of the refund for the service (no choice).

column1: - Other stores
column2: most notably Selfridges
column3: dont use global blue
column4: but instead give you a pre-addressed envelope. You return the stamped forms to them by post (can do once back in Switzerland
column5: but the envelope is pre-stamped for UK so may as well put it in the mail box at the airport). When they receive the form back they refund you the full amount to your credit card.

column1: The only catch in my exeperience when flying is that you need to have the goods (""intact"") with you through security to show to the customs office. So cannot be anything bulcky. It has to be small and valuable
column2: eg jewlery.   Some people say they have managed to find an HMRC officer before checkin and managed to get the form stamped there
column3: but I have looked many times and did not find anything.

Switzerland is racing to end a bitter dispute with Washington  over Swiss bank accounts held by US tax dodgers
column2: but observers warn the  new-found peace could come at a high cost.

column1: The lower house of the  Swiss parliament voted Monday in favour of a law that will require  Swiss banks to report the holdings of their current and future American  clients to US tax authorities.
The approval of the US Foreign  Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA)
column2: which aims to block Americans from  hiding money from the taxman in Swiss accounts going forward
column3: comes just  over a week after the Swiss government agreed to a separate deal to  help the country's banks make amends for past wrongdoings.

column1: Swiss  banks are believed to have accepted tens of billions of undeclared  dollars from US citizens
column2: though they now refuse such money
column3: and Bern  insists both recent deals are needed to end a dispute that has poisoned  relations between the two countries for years.

column1: Critics however  warn that the deal aimed at settling past wrongs
column2: which comes with stiff  fines attached
column3: could prove deadly for many Swiss banks.

column1: It's  devastating for Switzerland's financial industry
column2: said business lawyer  Douglas Hornung
column3: warning that even bigger penalties could be lurking  around the corner if European tax authorities decide to follow in  Washington's footsteps.

column1: The deal offers individual Swiss banks the  opportunity to avoid US prosecution if they agree to hand over  information on US citizens' accounts and to pay an ""appropriate"" fine --  assessed at 20-50 percent of the value of undeclared accounts
column2: depending on the time they were opened.

column1: Banks that opened  undeclared accounts for US clients before 2009
column2: when Washington launched  its battle by slapping UBS bank with a whopping $780-million fine for  complicity in tax evasion
column3: will face lower penalties.

column1: But fines will be stiffer for banks that scooped up tax-dodging US clients after that.
An  unspecified number of banks already under investigation by US  authorities will meanwhile not be eligible to take part in the  arrangement.
The Swiss Bankers Association (SBA) hailed the  agreement as a way for the banks to ""settle their US past quickly and  conclusively.""
But spokeswoman Sindy Schmiegel Werner acknowledged it was unclear how the Swiss banks would weather the storm.
We  don't know how exposed each of our members is
column2: she told AFP
column3: insisting  though that accepting the deal was necessary to clear away the legal  uncertainty that had been dogging the industry for years.

column1: Walter  Boss
column2: a tax lawyer with Poledna Boss Kurer AG in Zurich
column3: said  uncertainty was ""one of the worst enemies in the financial world.""

column1: But more clarity could come at a steep price
column2: even for banks that maintain they have done nothing wrong.

column1: Forced to cough up US client records
column2: they are basically being ""deemed guilty until proven innocent
column3: Boss said.

column1: Hornung was even more critical.
It's not really an agreement
column2: but more of a dictate from the United States
column3: he said.

column1: And  after suffering the onslaught from Washington
column2: the biggest danger could  lie ahead if European tax authorities decide to take the same route as  their American counterparts
column3: Hornung warned.

column1: Certainly

column3: the small banks simply can't survive
column4: he  cautioned.

column1: Schmiegel brushed  aside that concern
column2: pointing out that US tax law is very differen since  it is applied to all citizens
column3: regardless of where they live or work in  the world.

column1: I don't think the European Union will proceed the same way the US did
column2: she said.

column1: US tax law is meanwhile creating headaches in the run-up to the implementation of FATCA
column2: observers say.

column1: Fearing  the workload of ensuring compliance and especially the consequences if  they slip up
column2: ""banks have been actively eliminating American clients

column4: a Geneva-based tax expert working for the American  Citizens Abroad lobby group
column5: told AFP earlier this year.

column2: agreed lawyer Samuel Lohman
column3: who  specialises in international law.

column1: Since  FATCA applies to all American citizens
column2: regardless of their incomes or  fortunes
column3: this can have a devastating impact on a wide range of  Americans

column1: 2147	Financebankingtaxation	Capital gains tax rule in CH for sale of a UK property?	jammidge	2801	6	Location: zurich	30.08.2013
There is no capital gains tax in Switzerland
column2: at least in the way it operates in the UK.

column1: Instead you have to pay a ""fortune tax"" based on the assests you own on 31 Dec every year. This includes bank balances
column2: cars
column3: properties
column4: land
column5: etc. The annual tax is fairly small
column6: usually < 1 per thousand.

column1: So if you have an expensive vase that you sell for profit
column2: you wont pay any capital gains tax
column3: but next year your combined ""fortune"" will be slightly higher.   What's more
column4: foreign property is excluded from your ""fortune""
column5: so you dont pay fortune tax for it
column6: but foreign cash is included (but as mentioned
column7: we are talking of an extra tax of a few 100s per year a most).

column1: The only exception is Swiss real estate
column2: which has capital gains tax
column3: and can be high if you sell a swiss property in the first few years after you got it.

column1: Other thing to know
column2: is that Unlike UK
column3: Swiss tax ""gifts"". In the UK you gan give a home (or anything valuable) as a gift to someone (eg relative) tax free
column4: as long as the previous owner doesnt die within 7 years (or inheritance tax may be due). In Switzerlad gifts are taxable.

column1: So many people do this:
- when living in the UK => time to ""gift"" some valuable items (eg money) to my children / relatives
- when living in Switzerland => time to sell my shares
column2: and other valuables for profit.

column2: 21:05	"    The reason for the detour is the way ""clearance"" is organised.

column1: Obviously
column2: if someone sends money from bank A to bank B
column3: the money has to be transferred between the banks in one way or another. Banks do not transfer individual amounts between them
column4: they ""clear"" balances at the end of certain periods
column5: usually every day.

column1: Example: Bank A and Bank B do have direct clearance between them:
In one day:
100 customers transfer a total of 1million from A to B.
90 customers transfer a total of 900k from B to A.
At the end of the day Bank A owes Bank B 100k
column2: as this is the total difference.

column1: Now if bank A and B do not have direct clearance between them
column2: they work with their ""correspondence banks"" to enable the same clearance indirectly. For this
column3: they charge the (IMHO inappropriate) fee.

When I was in your situation a few years ago
column2: I just went down to the local tax office and they send a note with the new tax code to my employer's payroll. Up to here all well and good as they adjusted my code quickly and started to deduct tax at the lower rate.

column1: However
column2: 2 months later my husband started working again so we went back to the local tax office and again they adjusted the tax code. However
column3: this time my employer did not act on this so they under-deducted tax at source for 3 years and I had huge tax bills when I filed my tax returns as a result. I hadn't realised that was the reason why I had to pay more.

column1: I recently moved cantons and my employer received a notice with my new tax code. They then ""realised"" that they had under-deducted source tax and wanted to deduct back-dated even though I already paid via my tax returns. In the end we settled that they will just deduct the difference for 2013 - all of which does not make any sense to me as I will have a much lower tax bill for 2013 (lower tax location) and will get a repayment. But they insisted they must do it so I had a huge catch deduction - quite irritating.
Just mentioning all this as it is a good idea to check that our employer is applying the correct tax code.

I shipped a household of new goods from London to Switzerland after we bought a place and I left a UK licensed mover to handle everything
column2: including certifying export to Habitat and John Lewis the stores where we bought the stuff. In due course I received VAT refunds.

column1: The mover used a customs broker who had me sign documents regarding my move. I don't know exactly what was charged
column2: but my recollection is that there was no tax
column3: just fees.

column1: It isn't my job to understand the Swiss tax law; that's what customs brokers are paid for. If they get me a good deal I am glad.
An anecdote: Once
column2: when I was a diplomat in Abidjan I gave a businessmen's luncheon and one of the invitees was the manager of the embassy's customs broker. I commented with satisfaction that we as an embassy didn't have to pay any bribes. He laughed and said ""It's all hidden in the fees. We pay what has to be paid.""

column1: He knew his job and I didn't. There was a scandal with the embassy there once when
column2: as a result of a disagreement
column3: a container was held at the port until all the stuff in it had spoiled. The moral: Don't try to outsmart the experts.

column1: The moral risk in Switzerland is low; that was there and this is here.

But I have also used a shipper who advertises from time to time on this forum. He shipped new goods from London too and whereas he ""lost"" the tax papers and I never got the VAT refund I was expecting
column2: neither did I have to pay any tax nor did I get any border documents from his driver. They told me a long story that their van was unloaded at the tunnel from Italy but they still didn't have to pay anything.

column2: 16:40	"    As far as I'm aware (think I probably actually read it somewhere here on EF first  ) it is advisable to split up into different accounts
column3: e.g. when you reach say ca. 25k in one 3a account
column4: start a new one. The reason being that when you cash them in upon/after retirement
column5: you have to cash in the whole account (no part withdrawals) which you are then taxed upon (as income??). So if you have several smaller 'pots' you can withdraw one at a time as you see fit over time
column6: thereby minimising the tax impact in a particular year. So basically
column7: to my basic understanding
