column1: My daughter is a 2nd generation US person who was not born
column2: has never lived and scarcely visited the USA. Her child has no other US connection and (for want of qualifying residence of her mother) is not a US citizen.

column1: I'm not seeking advice but rather posting this to show the bizarre complexity of succession and tax planning given the scope (""éventail"") of IRS reach and FATCA (not to mention the notorious Form 3520 relating to trust funds and trust-like arrangements).

Almost any investment on behalf of this non-US child falls afoul of US law unless some unrelated non-US person (presumably at high cost) takes charge. Of course the situation could be worse: there is a notorious case of a developmentally-challenged adult in Canada who has never lived in the USA and who cannot renounce his jus-sanguinis US nationality but whose disability allowances are compromised:

It is no wonder that (judging from the discrepancy between the number of US citizens believed to live abroad and the number of tax returns and FBARs filed from abroad) so many dual nationals seem to throw away their US passports
column2: avoid US assets and ignore the IRS
column3: assuming that no future tightening of controls by the USG will force the Swiss Government (and the Canadian and other foreign states) to treat their own citizens as subject to foreign allegiance. Contrary to international law and practice
column4: but that doesn't seem to bother the Congress.

column3: all estates of ""US persons"" are subject to US federal estate tax (the US does not have an ""inheritance"" tax although some states do; inheritance taxes generally vary according to the relationship of the recipient (as does the German IHT; thus UK ""IHT"" is also an estate tax despite its name)). There will be a credit towards the US federal tax for any Swiss/cantonal inheritance tax paid. If there is property located in a US state or a state deems the person domiciled there
column4: it may also assess tax.

column1: That said
column2: there is no reciprocal tax collection agreement between the USA and Switzerland and thus if there are no assets of the succession in the USA there are no means for the IRS to enforce the tax unless the heirs have a US connection
column3: visit the US or have assets there.

column1: Read this memo
column2: formerly distributed by the Swiss Embassy in Washington:

column1: Civil-law ""succession"" is not by means of an ""estate"" (""une masse"" in French). The legal heirs and the testamentary heirs of any discretionary portion of the decedent's assets gain direct title. It may thus be difficult to achieve the unanimity needed to file IRS Form 709 and apportion the tax fairly among the heirs
column2: even more so if there are minors involved. If there is a surviving spouse
column3: the chances are nil that Swiss court will assist in the creation of a QDOT (you can Google that
column4: it's a trust that permits the postponement of US estate tax on assets passing to a spouse at death).

column1: But: there is a principle of ""transferee liability"" that would enable the IRS to seize any US assets of an heir to meet the estate tax (death duty) liability of that person in respect of inheritance from a decedent whose succession passed with unpaid tax. The fact that the decedent's offspring are (you say) American citizens suggests that the IRS will have jurisdiction over them. And where an executor or an administrator fails to file Form 709
column2: or is not appointed (or doesn't exist
column3: as in Swiss law)
column4: it is incumbent on the heirs to file it and pay any tax due.

column1: Bear in mind that few estates are actually subject to US estate tax. It is a base canard
column2: propagated by anti-tax people like Grover Norquist and by propagandists acting for the very rich
column3: that ordinary working people
column4: owners of small businesses and family farmers will have estates subject to the tax. In 2011 the exemption amount (unless changed by Congress) will revert to $1 million and the federal tax rate on amounts above that may be taxed at a rate up to 55%; in 2010 there is no estate duty at all. Google 'estate tax exemption' for more information.

Dear fellow EF members
I have been puzzled with a source tax issue and after looking through the threads in the forum with no luck I have decided to create a new post.
The issue here is on the exorbitant source tax levied on one-off bonus / large salary payments.
I used to work in Switzerland as an expat and left late 2011.
I was always taxed at source and filed a tax return at the end of the year to claim any overpaid tax. Most of this overpaid tax came from a bonus payment
which would normally be paid all in one month
column2: increasing the Quellensteuer rate for that month significantly.

column1: I never bothered asking my employer to spread out this amount over the year to decrease the monthly Quellensteuer as I was always able to claim it back from the tax return. Besides
column2: most employers would probably not bother doing it anyway.

column1: This is where things went wrong. I had a deferred bonus payment that I only received in 2012. I have been informed by my tax accountant and the Kanton tax office that as I had left Switzerland on the payment date
column2: I will not be able to file a tax return for 2012 and hence no return will be given.

column1: This sounds a bit silly as the high Quellensteuer rate is based on the assumption that this bonus amount is a recurring monthly payment while it is simply a one-off.
Under Quellensteuer Tariff A
column2: anything above 60k is taxed 24%. Assume that the payment was a one-off 60k you would have to pay this 24% tax. If this was distributed across the year resulting in 5k monthly payments the tax would be 3.16%.

column1: This means that you have effectively handed out 12.5k worth of tax you'll never see again.
Has anyone else had bonus / large payments paid out after leaving Switzerland?
If so
column2: were you able to claim some of this overpaid source tax back?

column1: I would really appreciate any advice.
Thanks.

column2: 15:06	"    What I told you was reality that you do not believe YET !

column1: Here is some information for you if you are daft enough to go the route you are thinking:

The introduction of bilateral agreements between Switzerland and the EU mean that in theory transfers of your UK Pension pot(s) into your Swiss second pillar are possible. Poor legal drafting on the Swiss side and the British nanny state make this a bit more complex in practise
column2: however it is not impossible.

column1: Before starting to jump through the hoops
column2: think carefully about doing this especially if you have a UK defined benefit pension as the transfer value is unlikely to be worth as much as a deferred pension. Also the transfer eats up part of your Additional Contribution possibility without getting the tax deduction. The most logical reason I have heard to want to do the transfer is to get enough money into the second pillar to be useful in a house purchase (see Accessing While in Switzerland). See Pension - Moving my UK pension to Switzerland

column1: So you still want to do it? An UK pension fund will only transfer pension benefits directly to an overseas scheme if that scheme qualifies under UK law as a QROPS scheme. These schemes need to comply with a number of fairly onerous reporting requirements towards UK HMRC
column2: and as a result only major international employers' schemes tend to go along with it. A list of QROPS schemes is available at   Swisscanto are not QROPs and have no plans to become so.

column1: If your employers fund is not a QROP and you are talking about a transfer large enough to make the fees worthwhile then there are several providers who can offer transit pension funds that are QROPs approved. Be aware however these providers are interested in building long term relationships not being ports of convenience. Some of these providers are referred to in this thread Freizuegigkeitskonto [vested benefit account]

column2: 18:24	"    Let's address you and your wife separately first
column3: and then together:

column1: You - From your profile I see that you're a British citizen. If you are not also a U.S. citizen/green card holder
column2: and if you did not earn any U.S. income in 2012
column3: then you do not need to file. Your income would not be included on your wife's return.

column1: Your wife - She earned income in the U.S. during 2012
column2: thus she is a resident for tax purposes for that year and will have to report worldwide income. She would file as ""married-filing separately."" You are wise to find an accountant to help you sort this out because...

column1: Together- In Switzerland married couples have to file a joint return. You'll need the accountant to sort out the taxes she paid here and whether she'll get credit for those on her U.S. return. It's possible your combined income for CH in 2012 was taxed at source or not high enough to file here
column2: in which case you'll have to track down that information in order to fill out your wife's U.S. taxes.

column1: Another catch - Because your wife will be a U.S. resident for tax purposes in 2012
column2: she *might* be subject to FATCA requirements. You can search the Forum for a bunch of info
column3: but basically if she (or the two of you together) held $10
column4: 000 or more in any account worldwide for even a day then that has to be reported on a separate form. Forum folks
column5: please chime in on this one because I could be and hope I am wrong!

column1: Going forward - In 2013
column2: assuming you and your wife are not citizens/green card holders and have no U.S. income
column3: you won't have to file again.

column3: calculates the tax for town and Kanton
column4: and then informs you.  They take the tax at source into account
column5: so often nothing to pay at this stage.

column2: and any remaining balance of tax at source.  You get then a different bill (or refund) when the federal tax people have done their maths.

column1: For 2011
column2: I got my local tax confirmation in September and the federal tax confirmation+ bill in January 2013.

2475	Financebankingtaxation	Can I open a Swiss bank account in England?	Symone	5303	8	Location: England	21.02.2013
Some points:
First of all
column2: to answer the main question
column3: you *cannot* open a Swiss account from London. Swiss law says that for opening an account the bank must meet the customer on Swiss terrotory (so you have to visit Switzerland at least once).

column1: First for the non-Swiss partner: Banks separate foreign customers as those living in Switzerland and those who dont. If you live here (and have a residence permit to prove it)
column2: opening an account is straightforward. If you do not
column3: then generally you can only open savings accounts (so no Maestro card or online banking) but most require at least 50000 franks or even more. Generally there are no monthly fees. But you may have to visit a big branch where they can deal with non-residents. Banks have a right to reject customers.

column1: Second for the Swiss national
column2: it is easier
column3: but again you must visit CH and also you face quite high charges if you are not living/working/have property here. Basically banks want ex-residents to close their current accounts when leaving (Credit suisse charges 40 CHF per month).

column1: So basically in your case it's best to wait and do as soon as you arrive. It takes no time at all
column2: you visit a bank and get the account number on the spot
column3: and you can then use online banking to tranfer from UK to Switzerland.

column1: 2509	Financebankingtaxation	Lombard Loans	Caviarchips	3630	14	Location: Basel Stadt	30.01.2013

A Lombard loan is similar to a deal with a pawn broker. You give some security and the bank makes no pretense at considering your ability to repay. You simply get a loan based on the security you can provide.
Here is how it could work happily in a rising market assuming you can borrow 70% of the value of the security . . .
Starting Capital in shares of value 100'000 Fr.
Use the original 100'000 Fr. shares packet as security and obtain a Lombard Loan for 70'000 Fr. which you use to purchase shares.
Use the  70'000 Fr. shares packet as security and obtain another Lombard Loan for 49'000 Fr. which you use to purchase shares.
Use the  49'000 Fr. shares packet as security and obtain another Lombard Loan for 34'300 Fr. which you use to purchase shares.
Use the  34'300 Fr. shares packet as security and obtain another Lombard Loan for 24'000 Fr. which you use to purchase shares.
Well
column2: you could carry on but let's assume you stop here.

column1: From your original 100'000 Fr.
column2: you have now over 270'000 Fr. in shares working for you
column3: busily earning dividends and increasing in value all for a miserable say 2 percent interest per year of the total loan. Wow. Lombard Lombard Lombard $$$.

column1: 2550	Financebankingtaxation	BCGE to BCV Customer - HELP	guest	2070	3	null	null	"    BCGE and BCV
column2: along with all other Cantonal Banks
column3: are not the same entities
column4: although they are organized and regulated by the Association of Swiss Cantonal Banks (Verband Schweizerischer Kantonalbanken / Union des Banques Cantonales Suisses).

column1: Each Cantonal Bank has a different ownership structure and many (particularly the two biggest ones like ZKB and BCV) engage in more sophisticated banking solutions.
BCV
column2: for example
column3: is a publicly traded entity in the Swiss Stock Exchange with approximately 2/3rd of the shares owned by Canton de Vaud. Under its charter
column4: the Canton de Vaud bears no legal responsibility to back a single centime under deposit (although there is a Federal Depositor Protection Scheme under the Swiss Banking Act which ensures ALL banks in Switzerland must chip in to guarantee up to 100'000 CHF per depositor in any Swiss bank going belly up).

column1: ZKB
column2: on the other hand
column3: is 100% owned by Kanton Zürich
column4: and all liabilities are fully backed by the Kanton. Whether this makes ZKB ""safer"" or not is hard to tell as it can create an incentive for more ""risk-taking"" in the bank itself. One can expect that if ZKB ever needs a bail-out
column5: it would be at a time when the economy in Zürich would be toast and the biggest tax payers in the Kanton (Credit Suisse and UBS) would themselves be under serious distress. Where would the Kanton raise money to bailout ZKB? Higher taxes (i.e. the depositors). In other words
column6: there really isn't such a thing as an unlimited Cantonal Guarantee since the depositors would have to bail out ZKB in one way or another.

2551	Financebankingtaxation	Phishing Alert - Fake IRS Email	guest	1481	7	null	null	"

A broader issue is that the US IRS will begin collecting non-US bank account data under a new law called FATCA. The IRS has NOT issued any data security guidelines regarding FATCA and many of us fear that this sensitive bank account data on Americans abroad may end up in the hands of terrorists
column2: extortionists and/or kidnappers. An editorial writer in Lebanon wrote an article called ""FATCA's Security Problem"" in December 2012. Here's an excerpt:

column1: However
column2: there is one aspect of FATCA that has not been sufficiently  examined
column3: but that remains potentially hazardous. The American  government is effectively asking foreign institutions to prepare  detailed data bases of American citizens
column4: with no guidelines explaining  how this information must be protected. For a country obsessed with the  security of its citizens in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks
column5: such  behavior is paradoxical
column6: indeed astonishing.

column1: Foreign financial  institutions will effectively become vast repositories of information on  Americansincluding what they earn
column2: the sources of their income
column3: what  they spend
column4: where they live
column5: who their family members are
column6: and so on. In  their zeal to implicitly label Americans living abroad as tax cheats  requiring monitoring
column7: the sponsors of FATCA have shown utter  indifference to the safety of their citizens.

column1: In some countries
column2: the American authorities are well aware that their enemies have ready  access to financial institutions. The Lebanese Canadian Bank scandal
column3: in  which bank managers were accused of helping Hezbollah launder money
column4: showed that this was true in Lebanon. What is to prevent anti-American  groups elsewhere from gaining access to data on American citizens
column5: and  possibly using this to their advantage? FATCA helps make it eminently  possible.

column1: Strangely
column2: we have heard nothing about FATCA from the  State Department
column3: which is responsible for Americans overseas. At a time  when American embassies regularly issue advisories to citizens to  guarantee their safety
column4: we are seeing the IRS asking institutions abroad  to gather the most sensitive facts on Americans
column5: with no oversight. The  irresponsibility is breathtaking. Worse
column6: because FATCA imposes pariah  status on Americans abroad
column7: whatever rightful protest they have against  the legislation will sound suspicious.""

I am no tax accountant or specialist but have researched this quite a bit over the last week...on if one should report Pillar 2 pension contributions on your US taxes as ""earned income"".
Summary
column2: you ask 5 tax accountants or advisers you get 5 different answers on if yes or how.

column1: Basically
column2: the tax treaty with Switzerland is pretty vague on the topic.  I have met US colleagues that have not included the pension as income & have filed w/o issues.  However
column3: it appears if one leaves Switzerland and requests for their pension funds to be released then a tax official from your home country must sign / stamp that they have been informed...so I'm not sure what would happen then if you had not reported it as income.  Therefore
column4: my conclusion is if you can fit it in under earned income with no additional tax burden (via foreign tax exemptions / deductions) then you should.

column3: but the total amount is correct. If every year 5'510 is contributed to the investment with 3.8% p.a. yield
column4: after 35 years the total will be:

column2: which is equal to the ""capital formation 397
column3: 243"". Just they divide the gain into two items ""interest and compound interest"" and ""capital gain"".

column1: Then they charge 23'431 CHF to the 3P
column2: I think it correspond to the tax to be paid when the 3P is withdrawn at once. They assume it because they are comparing to an alternative investment. The motivation of investment is not directly for putting money aside until retirement
column3: but for gaining money and having access to that money. If the 3P will not be ""cashed in""
column4: this 23'431 should be added back to the 3P return
column5: the result of which is still less than the alternative investment. In this sense this 23'431 is not very fair for 3P because it assumes that 3P will be cashed in. But the comparison can never be fair in this case. Assuming that with an alternative investment you will be forced to keep all the money till the very end (which you actually have access whenever you want) is at least as unfair as assuming you will be forced to cash in you 3P (which you actually can keep until the end). The two ways are just very different in terms of flexibility and availability.

First and foremost: No panic! I'm sure that you will be fine. There is no bad scenario here. French tax offices just want folk to fill in their tax forms properly and pay them the correct tax. They are not nasty.
Second: There is no rush. The tax year is not the calendar year. So I suggest you go and see them when you have time.
Third: As I said
column2: you have already paid tax on your salary in Switzerland. It cannot be taxed again in France
column3: due to the bilateral agreement. So there is nothing else to tax
column4: unless you have shares or some other source of unearned income. Even then
column5: there are allowances before the income becomes taxable.

column1: So
column2: good luck and don't worry  .

To get the tax forms
column2: your income is probably over 120K. The adjustment between the Quellensteur varies depending on where you live. In Zurich the Quellensteuer is lower than the local tax percentages
column3: so there's usually tax owing if you don't find lots of deductions. Even at 120K exactly (my husband earnt 500chf over one year  ) the adjustment was about 5000chf! That was in the city of zurich. I think for most areas it's the opposite - you could in fact get a reduction in your tax with the return and get a refund...

column1: I would definitely recommend you find a tax advisor to do your taxes. If you prepare all the information clearly
column2: they should not charge much. They should be able to tell you up-front what their normal fee is. We've been paying 150-200chf for an agent to do our returns...for two income earners (you are taxed together as a 'household' so the returns are all included together in the same documents).

column1: Hope that helps... it's a bit complicated with the variation between town to town
column2: depending on whether the employer has deducted the Quellensteuer properly in the first place
column3: and what other tax deductions you have. Our tax agent did provide an estimate on how much tax was owing
column4: but it was quite a bit higher than the actual.

column1: We also found it extremely easy to ask for a payment plan for the back-taxes. The bill came for around 3500chf and we asked for it to be split into three payments...no problem...two days later we got the pay-in-slips separated into three payments
column2: with the due dates on them...

column1: This all sound a bit jumbled up.  I am assuming we are talking about defined contributions here (not the rare Swiss animal defined benefit/final salary scheme).

Legal minimum contributions to the second pillar are based on age category and are to be shared as a minimum equally between employer and employee.  The employer can chose to contribute more and/or make both the employee and employer contribute more.

These contributions are based on your actual salary payments.  Your ability as an employee to make extra contributions will exists because your lifetime maximum contributions are based on your current salary and age related contribution %.  You might also be allowed to buy early retirement contributions.
Some of the contributions (say 1.5% of salary) go for insurance components (eg widows pension
column2: death in service) and administration.  The rest is your saving pot (guthaben/avoir veillesse) which is portable between employers (or into a free-movement blocked account freizugigkeits konto if you do not go directly back into employment).  The savings amount grows each year with tax free interest
column3: again there is a legal minimum rate and the employer can pay more too.

column1: When you go to a  new employer you just carry on saving each month. If that employer has higher contribution rates you will save more
column2: if less you will save less (even if you were already maxed out on extra contributions).

column1: When you retire you can take a mixture of lump sum or pension.  If you take a pension it is the last employer's pension fund that will determine the annuity rate you get from your saving pot (with a legal minimum rate).  If you take a lump sum you are taxed depending on your canton of residence if you still live in CH.

The pension fund manages the pensions savings of all the past and present members to be able to i) cover costs ii) pay annual interest on current members iii) be able to fund the transfers out and pensions until the last member dies (eventually). If there is a deficit of assets vs actuarial liabilities they may need to take measures to restore positive funding such as reduced interest
column2: higher funding etc.

column1: Thats a quick overview
column2: hopefully helpful.

We were in the same predicament.  This is what we did:
(1) We got a credit card with Capital One.  It has no annual fee
column2: no foreign exchange fee
column3: and a pretty competitive exchange rate (within about ~0.5%).  We use it for grocery shopping and big purchases.

column1: (2) We opened an account with PostFinance and did a wire transfer from BofA about a week later.  We didn't need to actually deposit any money to open the account at PostFinance.  It had a zero balance for a while.
BEFORE YOU LEAVE THE U.S.
column2: go to BofA and set up full authorization for phone wire transfers.  Wire transfers cost $45 a pop
column3: if done in dollars.

column1: Make sure you transfer dollars to dollars.  If you do dollars to Swiss francs
column2: BofA charges 5%.  They will tell you there is no foreign currency exchange fee but
column3: if you ask at what rate the money will be exchanged
column4: you will discover the hidden cost.

column1: PostFinance converted the dollars for us automatically.  The exchange rate was about 1% from market.

To wire transfer the money you need to give BofA the SWIFT code for PostFinance. The people at BofA don't always know.what that is. (The code for PostFinance is  .)    Try to locate a big branch of BofA in a big city where they have done this type of thing before.
(3) We brought U.S. dollars with us for immediate/emergency expenses.  We exchanged the money at the main train station in Zurich.  Exchanging the money was easy
column2: but it was also the most costly (3% for amounts over $3000 and 5% for under $3000).

Hi athgeneva.  I spent a lot of time researching this.  I talked to the IRS a few times via their 1-800 number
column2: but we never contacted a tax advisor.  The IRS told me that distributions from Swiss pensions are considered income.  As advised by the IRS
column3: we reported the total distribution on line 16a of our 2011 1040.  This was the ""Avoir de libre passage"" I mentioned previously.  We also had to fill out line 16b
column4: which is the taxable amount.  The IRS told me to take the total
column5: subtract the cost (i.e.
column6: her contributions to the pension)
column7: and report the rest on 16b.  Unfortunately
column8: we didn't have a complete history of her account
column9: so we had to make a best guess.  One of her statements showed her contributions and her employers' contributions separately
column10: so we used the amount from that statement as her cost.  As I said
column11: the total
column12: minus that cost
column13: is the taxable amount
column14: which we reported on line 16b.  Basically
column15: her employers' contribution and all interest was reported to the IRS.  We reported the same amounts to Massachusetts for our state returns.  Both our federal return and our state return were accepted
column16: but who knows if we'll be audited in the future.

column1: A lot of people claim that the IRS doesn't recognize Swiss pensions and therefore they are not taxed
column2: but that isn't true from what I've read of the US-Swiss tax treaty and from what the IRS agents told me.  It's possible that we overestimated the taxable portion
column3: but we figured what we did was safest.  Also
column4: for us
column5: because there wasn't that much money in her pension
column6: the end result wasn't much different if we changed the math.

column1: Let me know if you discover anything different.  Good luck!

Not having a credit profile won't stop you opening accounts when you get here.  It will only limit your ability to get credit.  If you're willing to put CHF 5000 credit into your credit card account when you arrive and never go below zero then some banks will give you a credit card.  Sure
column2: that means it's effectively a debit card rather than a credit card
column3: but it will get you started on building the credit history
column4: and aside from the one time transfer of the starting CHF 5000 balance
column5: you'll have no other FX costs ....

column1: However
column2: if you're not a fan of ""unnecessary costs""
column3: then prepare for a shock.  You may think its cheaper to run a local CHF credit/bank account than UK accounts
column4: but ... there's no free banking here in Switzerland.

column1: In other words
column2: it may not save you as much as you would hope to switch to a CH account: negligible credit interest
column3: CHF for a credit card
column4: CHF for a debit card
column5: CHF for transaction fees unless you have sufficient credit balance.  All the info is available on the banks' websites.  Take a look at ubs.com .  Or try the ""budget"" accounts offered by laposte.ch or migros.ch .

Apologies for the length of this message but I suspect many others out there in EF-land will be asking similar questions. I often see remarks on the forum about investment but I wanted specifically to ask for a little insight into the current (May 2012 ->) crisis in the Eurozone
column2: and what the options might be for the private investor.

column1: I have 3 UK-based investment accounts spread across a personal pension (50%)
column2: some tax-free ISAs (20%)
column3: and 30% in a general stocks and shares investment fund - tax payable. I can't close the pension fund till I retire in 10 years
column4: but the other two I can close any time I please. All of them give me total freedom to invest in the markets.

column1: In the last month
column2: the total value has dropped about 10%.

column1: After a rocky investment history over 10 years
column2: earlier this year I thought this time I am going to do some reading
column3: adopt a mainstream strategy AND STICK WITH IT WHATEVER HAPPENS.

column1: So I spread my cash over a variety of mainly steady
column2: well diversified sectors
column3: geographies and investment types. One difference this time is that I've been looking for a greater focus on income i.e. dividends to be reinvested.

column1: So now
column2: a few months in
column3: I'm seeing a significant loss
column4: but am still trying to stay mentally strong
column5: given the usual pattern of cashing out too soon (and then regretting it). However
column6: this time things seem worse
column7: with all sorts of apocalyptic commentary about the total collapse of various countries leading to a domino-style collapse across Europe and the capitalist world. I see no respite.

column1: I can feel my mouse finger itching to run to cash before I lose everything -- or an amount from which I will never recover.
Advice please! I know there are professional investors and bankers and financiers here. I am curious to know how you are dealing with the current situation
column2: professionally or privately.

column1: I suspect that my own financial arrangements as described are not untypical
column2: so if you were me
column3: what would you change
column4: if anything? Or would you just sit tight and ride out the storm (confident that the storm will have a sunny ending)?

column1: Thanks for any advice
column2: insight
column3: ridicule. Or please share your own investment dilemmas. At least we might feel a bit better if we jump off the Titanic hand in hand.

3091	Financebankingtaxation	Should I get married?	bigbeard	2189	24	Location: Rolle	06.05.2012
I have been in your girlfriend's situation
column2: though I was married. This is my experience to answer some of the questions above.

column1: She will need a visa. She needs to go to her local Gemeinde within 8 days of arriving in Switzerland to register and get her B permit. Yo should go with her to declare that you will support her. They may want some further declaration from you that you will continue to support her because you are not married - you should check on this before she arrives. Whether or not the permit says that she can work does not matter. As she is an EU citizen she is entitled to look for work here and when she finds a job she just goes to the gemeinde and tells them
column2: they will want a copy of her contract. (I started my new job last week :-)

column1: She cannot take out health insurance until she is resident here. I registered as resident before I came over here permanently - my husband was already here
column2: like you are
column3: so this was easy. The advantage of doing this before the last few weeks of pregnancy is that you can decide where to give birth
column4: have some checks with the midwives here
column5: and generally not be stressed about the whole thing. I continued to have check-ups in both CH and the UK in case there were any later complications that would prevent me coming to join my husband the month before my due date. Sure you pay a bit extra in a few months health insurance than if you leave it to the last minute
column6: but thats a small price to pay for peace of mind and good health.

column1: I continued to visit my husband and go back to London for work until i went on maternity leave and then I moved over here permanently. I was tax resident in both the UK and Switzerland for about 18 months. This is fine
column2: as long as you pay all your taxes to both countries.

column1: No one can tell you exactly how much tax you might save by getting married
column2: but in general Switzerland is supportive of the family unit and you will find your life here a lot easier as a family if you are married. If you decide not to
column3: don't forget to look up all the threads on here about having to declare your paternity etc
column4: and also check into the potential nationality implications for your child of being born in Switzerland to parents of different nationalities neither of which are SWiss.

column1: If you want further info on my experience feel free to PM me.

You say you are a US citizen
column2: therefore
column3: you are always a tax resident of the US irregardless of days spent in the US. You are fully subject to US Tax.

column1: The fact that you're telecommuting from Switzerland means that you are conducting business in Switzerland. You are taxable in Switzerland.
This is a typical expat scenario. If you remain on US payroll
column2: you need to fill out a Form 673 and request your Payroll manager from US Federal withholding. Also
column3: have them turn off state withholding if you've broken state residency. If you don't do this
column4: you will have cash flow issues.

column1: Side note: you risk the issue of having to pay Swiss social security if you don't apply for a certificate of coverage to exclude contribution on the Swiss side.
You will pay taxes in Switzerland. On your US return
column2: you will declare your world-wide income
column3: exclude a portion of it under foreign earned income exclusion. The residual tax amount not excluded can be reduced through your foreign tax credit (granted that they relate to your foreign work days).

column1: FYI
column2: you should let your company know that you're telecommuting from Switzerland. Depending on your role and responsibility
column3: you may have created permanent establishment for your company in Switzerland.         "	Posts: 765	Join Date: Dec 2011	Forum Veteran	Groaned at 6 Times in 4 Posts	Thanked 894 Times in 325 Posts	a reputation beyond repute

The following applies for Zurich (probably is similar in other cantons):
In order to ""overpay"" (or pay what you expect you owe due to changed circumstances
column2: i.e. higher bonus
column3: etc.) on the Federal Tax (Bundessteuer) you have to request a new payment slip. In essence you have to ask for a ""correction of the provisional invoice"".

column1: In Zurich you can do that online:

For the Cantonal/Commune Taxes you can use the blank payment slip and pay what you think is about right. I am guessing if you really use it as a interim deposit (i.e. paying twice the amount of last year
column2: etc. they'll probably give you a call).

Alpha should not be considered just returns above a benchmark. Firstly we are talking about EXCESS returns so the classical models say we adjust for risk free
column2: but most importantly alpha is the excess return we have (the intercept on a regression model) when we take into account ALL RISK Factors.

column1: Don't get sucked in by a fund manager who has made 4% over risk free when the S&P has a return of 2% above risk free. Far more likely his return is some alternative source of beta rather than true alpha.

Beta (market based returns) are still going to be the bread and butter of most peoples portfolios. That being the case the most sensible financial planning move most people can make is researching the cheapest way to take on this risk. ETFs are todays instrument of choice for that.

3209	Financebankingtaxation	pay taxes for property outside Switzerland?	elephant	5909	14	Location: BL	10.03.2012
Definitely worth checking out with a tax advisor
column2: as different cantons have different rules
column3: but from my understanding the situation is as follows:

column1: * all income should be declared
column2: as should your global wealth. These are taxed separately. Tax on fortune is really small (unless you are really
column3: really wealthy - and they you should definitely be seeking professional advice  )

column1: * Your income from movable assets (salary
column2: dividends
column3: etc) will all be put together to be taxed
column4: irrespective of where it has come from (i.e. irrespective of which country it has been earned in) - however
column5: you can also deduct tax paid
column6: loan interest etc
column7: etc.

column1: * Your income from immovable assets (property) is not taxed per se
column2: but is taken into account when working out your tax rate. The tax rate you pay on your overall income goes up depending on how much you earn
column3: so if you earn for example 50
column4: 000 CHF per annum you could be on 10% tax on that whole 50
column5: 000 CHF (these are made up figures by the way just to provide an example!). If you earned 75
column6: 000 CHF
column7: your tax rate on the whole amount (not just the 25
column8: 000 over 50
column9: 000) could go up to say 20% (again - fictitious rates
column10: but do note that the tax rate is not linear - it seems to go up exponentially after a while!). Again
column11: you can discount things like mortgage interest
column12: agent fees
column13: repairs

column1: So
column2: if in my fictitious example you earned 50
column3: 000 in a mixture of wages and dividends at a tax rate of 10%
column4: but then earned an extra 25
column5: 000 from property overseas
column6: you would end up paying 20% tax on your 50
column7: 000 CHF instead of 10% - so it is really a stealth tax   even though you would not be officially ""taxed"" on your 25
column8: 000 CHF of property income.

column1: With regard to past tax returns
column2: I had no idea about this when I got to Switzerland (was being taxed at source) and only found out after two years that if your assets are over a certain amount (not that high if you own property) you should actually do a normal tax return - at least in Geneva
column3: so we got an accountant to help us do backdated tax returns for 2008 and 2009. The GVA tax authorities were all ok with it - I think they are generally fine if a genuine mistake that someone is trying to rectify.

column2: 20:23	"    You have two separate issues here: inheritance law and tax law.

column1: (1) Inheritance law (and how a will should be written) is a state (not federal) matter.  If your mother does not have a will (valid per the law of the state where she resides)
column2: then the state will determine which heirs get what percentage(s).  You do not
column3: ever
column4: want to be in that situation.

column1: (2) Any ""US person"" under the tax code (which includes anyone holidng a ""green card"") is subject to federal estate tax.  There is no choice in the matter.  (Some states may levy an estate tax
column2: a further complication.)      The attorney & your mother are simply wrong. You do not have a choice about making Swiss law apply to a US resident.

column1: However
column2: you can (and should) have your mother go to a US attorney in her state of residence
column3: and draw a will
column4: for the reasons I noted above.

column1: Via careful planning (e.g. using gifts or a trust)
column2: much of the estate tax can be legally avoided.

I think you've misunderstood this a little bit.
The 3 pillar pension system here is all tax deductible
column2: i.e you can use that to reduce your taxable income.

column1: 1st Pillar is the AHV or the social security contributions
column2: this is deducted at source for all employees and is available for the self employed on a volunatary basis I believe.

column1: 2nd Pillar is the BVG
column2: which is also deductible at source and is offered by employers
column3: where they also contribute a similar amount to the one deducted from you. (not all employers have this)

column1: 3rd Pillar is a volunatary contribution into basically a locked savings account where the interest is paid without witholding tax
column2: and is taxed at a favourable rate (no idea exactly but there is a calculator somewhere) which is solely dependant on the amount saved within it at the time of cashout.

column1: However
column2: the third pillar concept has two parts a and b
column3: one is tax deductible and the other not
column4: and is simply a savings account
column5: basically something like if you want to have some extra money when you retire just shove it in a bank account somewhere.

column1: The monies put in the 3rd pillar account can not be used to trade securities by yourself
column2: however you can opt for a managed securities account with a predefined level of risk etc. I personally have never bothered. It is also worth noting that you can take the money out when you leave the country or use it as a security / pledge towards a deposit in a purchase of a property or when starting a business.

column1: This is how I understand it
column2: there might be some bits that might not be 100% but this is the general jist of things.

column1: 3249	Financebankingtaxation	Tax Change from ZH to Thalwil	CornishPasty	1791	2	Location: Horgen	24.02.2012
column2: 11:55	"    I assume by ZH you meant Zurich city?

column1: Tax deduction/withholding at source is based on the standard tables provided by each canton.  In your case
column2: the tables provided by Canton of Zurich.  There is NO difference in the withholding wherever in Canton Zurich.  The withholding is based on canton average and will not change just because you move from the city to Thalwil.  If you earn more than 120k a year
column3: then you'll eventually be filing your tax and you'll pay the difference or receive a refund.  If you're under 120k
column4: you can still file for an adjustment
column5: though not required.

column1: However
column2: since your move from Zurich city to Thalwil involves no change of canton
column3: you will NOT be benefiting from the lower tax rate in Thalwil for 2012.  For the entire year of 2012
column4: you will be treated for tax purpose as someone living in Zurich city.  The lower tax in Thalwil will only kick in beginning in 2013.  This is how it works with the tax code.  Unless you move to a difference canton later in 2012
column5: you'll be taxed as Zurich city
column6: not Thalwil.

column1: ps. If you do change canton during the year
column2: then it's pro-rated.  Within the same canton
column3: it's based on where you live/register on 1/1/xxxx of the year.

column2: 19:26	"    almeida: Pension accounts
column3: per the IRS
column4: are maintained (under the  control of) either (a) the beneficiary (your wife)
column5: or (b) someone else  (your wife's employer
column6: or the gov't).  Examples: an IRA account is in  group (a)
column7: a pension plan or social security account is in group (b).

column1: So
column2: the issue if very simple: who holds the funds (is the custodian) for  a ""2nd pillar"" account
column3: and can the beneficiary (your wife) change that  custodian
column4: or change the investment of funds?  (""Yes"" to either = you  should file the FBAR; ""no"" to both = don't file.)

column1: The IRS has not issued a formal opinion on CH pensions
column2: and pensions are  not explicitly addressed in the FBAR form instructions.  In practice
column3: that means the IRS is not about to prosecute folks on this matter.

People have mutliple approaches. People with loads of Money give it to some Swiss / International money managers.
Smart people with relatively less money handle it themselves by investing it selectively into Stocks and commodities.
There are people who don't bother or want to actively track and play the market so they keep them in deposits.
I personally think in todays situation in Switzerland Deposits are ridiculous. Playing in stock is not advisable unless you think you are one of those smart people who can track and play it.
If you have loads of money couple of millions or above then give it to banks so that they can manage to earn the service fee which keeps the larger part of professional community employed.

I think selective long term buying in  Commodity (Oil) and Precious metal is good but then not a guarantee. There are good companies out there with reasonable dividend yields and returns but could fall prey to market fluctuations.
Decide where you can go. Actually we could have a little monthly meet up to discuss markets and investment opportunities

column2: 18:19	"    It isn't against the treaty
column3: the combined income is used to determine the tax rate as it would be if everything was earned in Switzerland
column4: but the tax already paid in the UK is taken into account so you don't end up owing any more on income already taxed in the UK.

column1: I appreciate it's frustrating as I've been through it but I also see the Swiss perspective that you can't have the tax benefits of being married without the downsides.
Btw I often see the double taxation agreements referred to in the context of not being 'taxed twice on the same income'
column2: but this description is slightly misleading to anyone who is new to the topic. Obviously the agreements differ between countries and the finer points often change
column3: but mainly they only limit your liability to the amount of tax that would be due in the highest taxation country
column4: so if you live on the lower tax country (eg Switzerland) and a higher tax country (eg UK) decides you are subject to it's tax laws too
column5: you can in fact be taxed twice but your second bill will take into account what you gave already paid so you only owe the difference.

column1: I am not sure I know all the facts well enough but my understanding is that if you are employed (as opposed to self employed) and earn less than CHF 120k you are not required to do a tax return.  Your tax is deducted from your monthly salary by your employer.

This deduction at source is calculated based on the average tax rate for the canton.  So depending upon where you live in the canton you might be slightly worse or better off depending upon whether where you actually live has a higher or lower tax rate (and may wish to do a proper tax return).

If you have paid into a 3rd pillar account and earn less than CHF 120k there is a form that you need to complete and submit (I think by 31 March) for every tax year to get the tax back in respect of your 3rd pillar contribution.
If you earn more than CHF 120k you will be doing a tax return anyway and claim the deduction in that.
It seems like you will end up paying tax twice on the amount unless someone who knows more than me knows of a way around this.  Sorry....

column2: bank in London).  Bargain!  But the amount credited turned out to be 7 CHF less than I sent
column3: so I assume Oanda's bank took that.

column1: 3. Oanda charge for the transfer. It's very transparent and I believe my charge came to around 20 CHF.

column2: I got exactly that amount in my UK account (a day later). I was happy.  It matched or beat (I forget) the XE.com rate I usually use to check.

I have been an IT contractor in the UK for a very long time and is currently in the middle of move to Switzerland. I might be able to help with this expense thing as I lived out of a suitcase for a long time.
First of all
column2: where is your salary is being paid? in the UK or in Switzerland? If it is UK
column3: then you have nothing to worry about tax as it is all PAYE. (my understanding is that you are an employee)

column1: Secondly
column2: there is something call P11D per year that you need to fill in if you claim expenses. That is expenses paid out of your pocket and even if you claim in full
column3: you still have to pay for it. The thing HMRC is going to get you on most is private car use (i.e. mileage allowance). So to avoid this paperwork
column4: get a company credit card and use taxi/public transport for ALL your expenses
column5: then you do not have to fill this in. Besides having a company credit card
column6: it is down to your company to sort out the bills; just remember to keep all receipts.

column1: Thirdly
column2: try not to do this shuttling too much. A week split into two places are going to get to you very quickly. I can cope with one location once a week
column3: even with that I tends to do like ""commuting"" every fortnight. It is not about the cost but your time as well. Traveling is dead time. You have to get to airport early
column4: hang around
column5: delay
column6: waiting for luggage etc. I could write a book about airport and airlines
column7: especially BA! The novelty will wear off very quickly. Besides if you only in Switzerland 3 days a week with no weekend
column8: you got your workload to finish
column9: so early start - late finish; when are you going to experience the Swiss life?

column1: Just my 2p worth.   (still can't work out the equalvant in CHF)

The key point is were you and when taxed under withholding tax or direct tax regime. The former would basically be if you have a permit B
column2: do not own Swiss property and are not married to a Swiss
column3: and this even if you filled out a tax return etc.  Your data doesnt quite make this clear enough.

column1: Under the withholding tax regime you are taxed on your earnings in the cantons you lived in when you earned the money.  This is different from the direct tax regime where you are taxed in full for that year in the canton of residence at 31.12.
This is complicated enough
column2: but you have split tax regime and split year
column3: and all in December.  So for example I think the switch to direct tax comes in the month after your change... but Im not sure.

column1: Calling the tax office is a great idea
column2: and if they dont give you a clear and unambiguous answer you will need to get a bit of knowledgeable advice.  In ZG go to Bruno Bosshardt (no connection but did help me with a similar problem a few years ago).

column1: What however is pretty sure is you can choose to pay less than the tax bill from ZG if you genuinely believe your final tax bill in ZG will be nil.

column2: to get back to this thread with the answer

column1: Well
column2: in short Mgosia was right!

column1: The authorities tax everyone as if they work 100%. BUT
column2: your employer just need to fill out a declaration
column3: that you're only at x-percent
column4: and therefore just need to pay the corresponding taxrate. This can be done when you begin your work
column5: and so the tax-office won't send you a bill.

column1: If
column2: you already have payed to much
column3: just go to the tax-office and explain the situation. Your employer will have to sign the declaration regarding your working percentage
column4: and then you will get your money back - in the end of year I suspect...

column1: I don't know if it's only possible for the past year or how it works.

column2: we didn't have to pay anything because we're leaving CH and therefore the tax office would speed up the process and instead of giving us our money back in the end of 2011
column3: we didn't have to pay now.

column2: 14:18	"    Generally you should expect to receive a small bill. The usual reason for this is that there has been an extra payment such as a 13th salary or a bonus that is then annualized. ie the average monthly salary is increased and this is then extrapolated to give your synthetic annualized salary. You might think that you pay per month the correct amount but this is all done according to an annualized table and not each month totally individually. If your salary pro rata was high enough you can then make some decent deductions which will produce your anticipated refund.

As far as I know
column2: and I'm not an international tax or company lawyer...

column1: If you work in Switzerland
column2: you have to pay Quellensteuer (= tax at source - think PAYE). When you were an employee of the agency
column3: they should have made this deduction before paying you. Working via a UK ltd company is problematic. As a Swiss resident
column4: you're obliged to pay Swiss taxes. Did your UK ltdco make and tax payments on your behalf? I'd guess not. And therein lies the problem. The Basel tax authorities want their cut. The agency have discovered they've screwed up royally.

column1: If you do owe tax
column2: then the agency may be right in withholding it. You should demand a complete breakdown and explanation of deductions. Tell them that if they don't give you this breakdown then you will raise the issue with the Basel tax authorities. You should probably take some local legal advice.

column1: Here's a quick summary of what I've found out so far

column1: Living in   - I'd have a 'G' permit

column3: pay fix 4.5% Quellensteuer to the Swiss
column4: and then fill in a tax return to the Germans to pay their tax too
column5: apparently as a rule of thumb around 25% in 4 bills per year. The tax paid already to the Swiss gets deducted from the German tax bill.  Plus as you say I'd have the traffic through the Bregenz bottleneck.

column2: pay around 9% Quellensteuer to the Swiss
column3: then fill in a tax return to the Austrians to pay their tax on top
column4: but this time it's up to 50%

column6: but still...

column1: Living in   - I'd have a 'B' permit and pay regular full Quellensteuer to the Swiss
column2: and that's it.  So this would make the income tax a lot less than the other two options
column3: but make the rent perhaps a bit more (but not as much more as I thought).

column2: 11:45	"    Basically works like this:

column1: The value of non-swiss property is added to your total asset value to determine your swiss wealth tax rate.
You then pay wealth tax on world-wide liquid assets (ie bank accounts)
column2: but not on non-swiss property. Only swiss property is subject to swiss wealth tax.

column1: The value of income derived from non-swiss property (eg: rental income) is added to world-wide income and affects the overall swiss income tax rate.
Of course
column2: you must fulfill any tax obligations in the property's home country (income tax
column3: wealth tax
column4: etc)

column1: To make things slightly complicated
column2: the calculation of how much of the non-swiss property is used to add to your global wealth is not so straightforward.

column1: So a tax consultant may be required.
As for evidence: provide any documentation you have stating the property value
column2: and any income generated eg: council rates notice based on government assessed property value
column3: etc. And of course don't forget to claim the associated property deductions
column4: including any mortgage on the property.

kiwiguy - the reason that filing a full tax form *might* be beneficial for you is that the Gemeinde tax rate in Horgen (which you would pay if you file) is much lower than ZH canton (the rate used for Quellensteuer). Also as you mentioned
column2: the months you received bonus payments had higher QS deductions - if you file a tax return these amounts are effectively averaged over the year
column3: rather than producing a couple of months of higher rate taxation (ie you paid 'too much' under QS).

column1: It may be worth your time downloading the tax filing software from   and filling in a dummy return.  If you have basic German knowledge
column2: a 2009 Lohnausweis (you should have) and few other financial assets (investments
column3: savings
column4: property etc) then it should not take long and it will calculate your tax liability with all appropriate deductions accounted for.

column1: Having said all that
column2: if your total tax liability under QS was 7900
column3: the difference may not be that great (a few hundred sfr ?) - maybe just forget about it and save all the hassle.

column1: 4182	Financebankingtaxation	Help calculating real tax	ghost	1967	6	Location: Zurich	18.11.2010
Quellensteuer is charged at the average 'gemeinde' (community) tax rate.  As a forigner newly in Switzerland you will have this deducted from you monthly salary.  It is not normalised over the year
column2: so can vary considerably if you salary varies month by month
column3: especially if you have a 13th salary payment or bonus.

column1: As your earnings exceed 120k
column2: you will be required to additionally file a tax return.  The calculations for this are dependent on your 'gemeinde'.  If you live in a relatively high tax gemeinde e.g. Zurich city
column3: you will find that this assessment yields a higher tax liability that you will have paid via quellensteuer.  You will eventually be invoiced for this difference (can take a long time
column4: so you can accrue substantial liabilities).  It is therefore worth considering living in a lower tax gemeinde
column5: although note that this often involves higher rental/property prices
column6: less good travel connections or other disadvantages.

column1: "	Posts: 44	Join Date: Nov 2009	Junior Member	Groaned at 1 Time in 1 Post	Thanked 11 Times in 10 Posts	made some interesting contributions
4184	Financebankingtaxation	2nd Pillar - move to UK	Dr Winston O'Boogie	2047	3	Location: Zurich	19.11.2010
Your 2nd pillar is in two parts - the mandatory element and the extra-mandatory element.

The mandatory element (sometimes referred to as 'in accordance with BVG') may no longer be paid out in cash to someone who leaves Switzerland for an EU/EFTA country which has mandatory occupational benefits for old age.  This mandatory element is the contributions you made at the mandatory age-related percentage against the 'coordinated' salary
column2: that salary I believe is limited to approx. 85
column3: 000 sfr.

column1: Anything more you contribute (ie a higher percentage of salary
column2: or a higher insured salary) becomes part of the extra-mandatory element.  This usually is less secure
column3: less regulated and attracts a different (read lower
column4: variable) return in the pension.  However
column5: assuming your pension policy allows it (and some may impose their own restrictions)
column6: it is possible to make early withdrawal of this money when leaving Switzerland
column7: even if moving to an EU/EFTA state.  If there are early withdrawal restrictions on your policy
column8: you may be able to circumvent these by transferring the pension to a Freizügigskeit account which has no such restrictions when your employment is terminated.  This can be advantageous anyway
column9: as you can choose a Freizügigskeit account whose 'Stiftung' (trust) is located in a lower tax Kanton.  The tax you will pay when cashing in the pension from abroad will be based on this location instead of your location of residence (as you are no longer Swiss resident).  You should plan for this tax - if your extra-mandatory element is large (100
column10: 000+) the taxes can start to become large also
column11: and may not be paid out of the money withdrawn (ie you must pay the tax first
column12: before you receive the pension money - at least that is the rule if withdrawing pension money for house purchase within Switzerland).

4203	Financebankingtaxation	US tax libilities on CH Pension .Help wanted!	philg	2573	5	Location: louisiana usa	30.10.2010
The US-CH tax treaty
column2: Article 18
column3: states ""pensions and other similar remuneration beneficially derived by a resident of a Contracting State in consideration of past employment shall be taxable only in that State.""

column1: So
column2: if you are a US resident
column3: you are liable to for tax on any pension income
column4: no matter the source.

column1: For US pensions and ""similar"" structures (IRA accounts)
column2: you are not taxed until you withdraw the income.  I believe the IRS applies the same principle to foreign pensions.  So
column3: if you leave the funds in the account created
column4: imvho you are liable for tax only on the income withdrawn.  (The same point for interest: if you did not withdraw it
column5: it is not taxable.)  However
column6: that is a question best put to a US tax accountant
column7: and it should not be costly to obtain that advice.

column2: ten men go out for beer and the bill for all ten comes to £100.If they paid their bill the way we pay our taxes
column3: it would go something like this..

column1: The first four men (the poorest) would pay nothing.
The fifth would pay £1.
The sixth would pay £3.
The seventh would pay £7.
The eighth would pay £12.
The ninth would pay £18.
And the tenth man (the richest) would pay £59.
So
column2: that's what they decided to do.     The ten men drank in the bar every week and seemed quite happy with the arrangement until
column3: one day
column4: the owner caused them a little problem. ""Since you are all such good customers
column5: he said
column6: ""I'm going to reduce the cost of your weekly beer by £20. Drinks for the ten men would now cost just £80.     The group still wanted to pay their bill the way we pay our taxes. So the first four men were unaffected. They would still drink for free but what about the other six men? The paying customers? How could they divide the £20 windfall so that everyone would get his fair share? They realized that £20 divided by six is £3.33 but if they subtracted that from everybody's share then not only would the first four men still be drinking for free but the fifth  and sixth man would each end up being paid to drink his beer.     So
column7: the bar owner suggested that it would be fairer to reduce each man's bill by a higher percentage. They decided to follow the principle of the tax system they had been using and he proceeded to work out the amounts he suggested that each should now pay.

column1: And so
column2: the fifth man
column3: like the first four
column4: now paid nothing (a100% saving).

column1: The sixth man now paid £2 instead of £3 (a 33% saving).
The seventh man now paid £5 instead of £7 (a 28% saving).
The eighth man now paid £9 instead of £12 (a 25% saving).
The ninth man now paid £14 instead of £18 (a 22% saving).
And the tenth man now paid £49 instead of £59 (a 16% saving).
Each of the last six was better off than before with the first four continuing to drink for free.     But
column2: once outside the bar
column3: the men began to compare their savings. ""I only got £1 out of the £20 saving
column4: declared the sixth man. He pointed to the tenth man
column5: ""but he got £10!""   ""Yeah
column6: that's right
column7: exclaimed the fifth man. ""I only saved a £1 too. It's unfair that he got ten times more benefit than me!""   ""That's true!"" shouted the seventh man. ""Why should he get £10 back
column8: when I only got £2? The wealthy get all the breaks!""   ""Wait a minute
column9: yelled the first four men in unison
column10: ""we didn't get anything at all. This new tax system exploits the poor!"" The nine men surrounded the tenth and beat him up.     The next week the tenth man didn't show up for drinks
column11: so the nine sat down and had their beers without him. But when it came time to pay the bill
column12: they discovered something important - they didn't have enough money between all of them to pay for even half of the bill!     And that
column13: boys and girls
column15: is how our tax system works. The people who already pay the highest taxes will naturally get the most benefit from a tax reduction. Tax them too much
column16: attack them for being wealthy and they just might not show up anymore. In fact

column1: example:

rate at airport in the UK will be more or less the same rate in an Airport in Switzerland! i.e both a rip off!! Never ever buy currency at airports! Airports charge the highest spread you can think of!
From my experience without anything to back it up with
column2: the spreads are ranked below from high (bad) to low (as good as you gonna get)   How do you work out the spread?

column1: Well when you go to buy the currency you're interested in ask for the bid/ask for the currency pair (they usually flip it at the airport
column2: so the ask is displayed in front of the bid with titles like we sell (the bid) and we buy (the ask) which is confusing and somehow makes the customer think they're getting a better deal than they actually are:

column1: anyway here is an example
GBP/CHF:MID1.5260 (source: swissquote 2010/10/25 13:22) This is the best price you can get at this given time.
Airport price: [5% spread] so if you want to exchange GBP to CHF
column2: The airport (agent)'s bid for your pounds is 2.5% the MID quoted above and in this case it is 1.5260 x (1- 0.025) = 1.48785
column3: their ask for the GBP is gonna be 1.5260 x (1 + 0.025) = 1.56415.

column1: So for a GBP1000 you would get CHF1487.85.
and if you want to buy GBP you would have to pay 1.56415 for every pound.
in the Airport you will see it quoted as
(UK FLAG)     We Sell (1.56415) We Buy (1.487.85)
[ As you can see this is confusing as it seems to the customer that they're going to get 1.56 when in fact they are going to get 1.48 for every pound ]
Let me know if you need more information
column2: for small amounts I find it better to just exchange with friends who need the opposite currency.

column1: Swiss tax returns work on the following basis:
You must declare global assets and global income
You are charged tax on your Swiss assets only

You can claim the actual tax paid on any overseas income (if it was taxed in the country it was earned in) to prevent any double taxation. Valid for all countries where a double taxation agreement exists.
As for costs
column2: you can claim either a fixed amount for work related expenses
column3: or actuals (proof required)

column1: You get child benefits
You get travel related expenses
If you work out of home
column2: you can claim part of your home as work-related expenses

column1: But always best to see a tax expert
column2: especially if you have overseas property and overseas rental income.

column1: - never ever withdraw EUR in Switzerland (the rate used is 'banknote exchange rate'' which is much worse than normal bank rate)

column2: but much better rate than if you pay in EU with CHF card.  This means it is worthwhile having two accounts in Switzerland alone (EUR and CHF).  Pay with CHF bank card when in CH; and with EUR bank card when abroad.

column1: - payments abroad from UBS EUR account are having 1% additional fee; but it is still better than paying with card associated with CHF account

If you have a B permit
column2: you are subject to taxation at source in Geneva
column3: unless your gross income exceeds CHF 500'000 per year OR if you have taxable wealth in Geneva (which you probably have). If you are in one of those situations
column4: you have to file an annual tax return
column5: which will put you in exactly the same situation as C permit holders (which are no longer subject to tax at source).

column1: The rate is different as the tax at source rate already includes some lump-sum deductions and is calculated on your gross salary whereas the ordinary rate is computed on your net taxable salary
column2: i.e. after all effective or lump-sum deductions. It is usual to say that after a salary of CHF 100'000
column3: it is more advantageous to file a tax return
column4: especially if you contribute to a 3rd pillar or make additional contribution to a second pillar (which will be taken in account only if you file a return). This is why in most of the canton the limit for the mandatory return for people being taxed at source is CHF 120'000. Whereas Geneva
column5: as always
column6: follows its own rules...

column1: Comparing tax rates won't help you any further (not computed on the same base)
column2: you need to compare the total of taxes for people exactly in the same situation (same salary
column3: same transport costs
column4: meal costs
column5: etc.)
column6: which is likely not not exist...

I realise this is an old topic
column2: but it’s been bothering me. There have been some good discussions on the future of the UK system
column3: but could we look at the current situation for a moment for those retiring in the UK? I’m going to make some simple assumptions. First assumption: the cost of a qualifying year is roughly £625. Second assumption: one extra qualifying year gives you £169 a year extra on your State Pension (£3.25 a week).

column1: If you ‘live’ on State Pension alone
column2: you have (maximum) roughly £5
column3: 070 a year. You soon discover that you can’t ‘live’ in the UK on this amount. You require extra (means tested) benefits just for a basic lifestyle.

column1: Therefore you save
column2: or invest
column3: and sacrifice whilst below pension age. Upon retirement
column4: the result is a yearly income of £17
column6: or a total income of £22
column7: 500 a year. Because you’re age 65
column8: your personal allowance is roughly £9
column9: 500 and you’ll pay 20% tax on the remainder (£2
column10: 600 tax). You’re now only slightly worse off financially than the average UK worker. You probably won’t qualify for any means tested benefits.

column1: The trouble is you don’t really fancy a lifestyle “only slightly worse than the average UK worker”. You sacrifice more. The result is a yearly income of £24
column2: 000 a year
column3: or a total of £29
column4: 000 a year including the State Pension. There is one problem though. Your personal allowance is now only £6
column5: 475 a year (standard personal allowance) even though you’re 65 or older. You’re now paying £4
column6: 505 a year in taxes
column7: or almost 90% of your State Pension. The extra £6
column8: 500 of income has only netted £4
column9: 600 after taxes.

column1: But your spouse refuses to fly Ryanair on holiday. So
column2: more sacrifice for a retirement income of £50
column3: 000 a year. It would be comprised of a £40
column4: 000 pension
column6: 000 UK State Pension
column7: and £5
column8: 000 in taxable interest on a fair amount of savings. You’ve now followed the Government(s) advice and provided adequately for your retirement
column9: and have some savings as well. It’s also £9
column10: 330 a year in taxes
column11: with the last £6
column12: 125 of income at the 40% rate (that’s 40% tax on all your taxable savings income
column13: plus. At least your ISAs aren’t taxed for now).

column1: At these income levels
column2: you’re not only paying yourself for your own State Pension but you’re also paying nearly a full State Pension (in benefits) for your next door neighbour who has by choice never worked a day in their life. You now understand some of the motives behind the Governments need for you to be able to provide for yourself in retirement. You’re struggling to understand how
column3: simply as a self-sufficient pensioner
column4: you are suddenly part of the large group that is a financial burden on society. It appears to be the other way around.

column1: I agree with Andy02
column2: the UK Government will not want old age “benefits” of some description to disappear. The UK has too many people locked into a “benefits lifestyle”. I recently heard (Michael Portillo
column3: I think
column4: on the “This Week” programme) that 1/3 of all UK households depend on benefits for at least 50% of their income. Well
column5: he was a Tory. He would point that out. As Andy02 said
column6: the UK and US systems are skewed to benefit the low paid.

column1: To some extent
column2: I agree with Cashboy. “Who is the mug?” There’s a lot of sacrificing going on in some of those scenarios
column3: and not by your next door neighbour. (Let me quickly say that I support benefits for those who have found themselves in unfortunate circumstances. Many do deserve assistance.)

column1: And finally for the OP
column2: crazysniper. Obviously
column3: you will decide which of the above scenarios you want to live in. If it’s £5
column4: 000 a year only
column5: then the extra £3 a week won’t matter. You’re “guaranteed” a basic amount if your total income and assets are low enough (pension credits). If you have one of the other scenarios in mind
column6: it is a pretty “paltry” sum. Even so
column7: every Pound counts. But it’s not automatically £3 a week
column8: (and for simplicity) it can be only £1.80 a week
column9: or less
column10: thanks to tax. Once retired
column11: and provided you’ve sacrificed (or should that be “planned wisely”)
column12: tax brackets and inflation will be your real concerns.

column1: Go for your 2055 equivalent of the £50
column2: 000 scenario. You won’t have to fly Ryanair or whoever it is then
column3: and you can imagine that with your tax payments you’re actually helping to prevent a few fellow old age pensioners from starving. Realistically though
column4: it’s tax revenues
column5: and won’t be used to pay pensions. It will just barely cover the expense of some MPs fact finding mission to Greece to discover ways of stopping these damned old age pensioners from being such a drain on the system. Most depressing of all
column6: in the future we’ll look back on this situation as the good ol’ days. Most worrying of all
column7: I sound like some right wing Republican!

column1: I know there’s nothing new here
column2: and I apologise. It just seems that looking at the actual figures clarifies the likely possible pain for anyone planning to provide for their own retirement. Once all your income (from pensions
column3: savings
column4: investments
column5: etc.) reaches £28
column6: 930 a year (with the reduction starting at £22
column8: you’re treated for income tax purposes equal to anyone else who is working. The Chancellor has no intention of rewarding you in any way for your valuable diligence
column9: even if you are on a State Pension. Any tax proposal that increases the income tax for those workers affects you equally
column10: such as a change in thresholds or an increase in tax rates. This is not meant to discourage those who are planning for a self-sufficient retirement. It’s simply a reality check.

The ""Eigenmietwert"" (valeur locative) is the theoretical rental value the tax authorities computes to properties occupied by the owner or used by him. It does not apply to properties rented out (in that case only the rental income is added to the other income
column2: not the rental value). If a second house is partly rented out and partly used by the owner (let's say 50/50)
column3: then the rental income for the 6 months will be added to the other income and the theoretical rental value for the other 6 months will be added also. The full rental value does not come in addition of the rental income
column4: only the part that correspond to own use. The tax saving door quickly opens: how will the tax authority know how much days you have rented it out and how much days you occupied it for your own usage? It depends what you declare on the tax return. And I would clearly try to reduce as much as possible the part of own occupying... (if I had a second house indeed...)

column2: 14:21	"    In terms of your lifestyle
column3: plenty or none
column4: depending on your point of view.

column1: In order qualify as non domiciled you need to cut all links to UK. Links mean things like property there so you couldn't keep a home in the UK - freehold or leasehold - so no boltholes. Also intending to retire there or be buried there when the times comes will qualify as a link so you can't do that. The Revenue would also look at the amount of time you spend there so visits should be kept to a strict minimum. Even educating your children there or maintaining banks accounts
column2: investments or other assets there might constitute a link. There is no acid test - the courts would look at all the circumstances before deciding whether you were domiciled in the UK or not. The golden rule is the less you have to do with the UK the better. For many people
column3: the downside of the family/social implications of cutting all links to the UK outweigh the upside tax advantages.

column2: 18:06	"    In the case of a court judgment from another EU/EEA/Swiss country enforcement is easy: the judgment can be registered locally under the Lugano Convention (parallel to the old EU Brussels Conventions on Jurisdiction and Enforcement of Judgments
column3: now the ""Brussels Regulation""). There is no right to defend except under extremely limited circumstances (such as you happen to share the same name with the debtor and furthermore were never served with the writ).

column1: The problem in many of these cases is that credit card and other debts are sold off by financial institutions to speculators and collection agencies for pennies
column2: and then the buyer proceeds aggressively. I've seen this happen even when the debtor had been discharged in bankruptcy
column3: although normally that's a perfect defence. Claim of payment is also a defence
column4: unless that was raised
column5: or could have been raised
column6: in the foreign proceeding.

column1: There is a principle called "" ""
column2: included in the Convention
column3: that encourages a race to the courthouse in the most favourable jurisdiction because once an action (such as libel or divorce
column4: although family law cases aren't covered by the Convention) has been started in one signatory state an action in another
column5: except for enforcement or attachment
column6: is precluded. That's why the English small claims courts can be useful.   (Indeed the French small claims system ( ) is also helpful when they have jurisdiction
column7: and there's is the additional advantage that they are free and gratis
column8: unlike the English ones.)

column1: Often the cheapest way to address unfair pursuit for debt is through the English administrative bodies responsible for unfair trading. For example
column2: some claims are for fees charged by for-profit vocational schools that immediately sell off the instalment agreement and then either go into receivership or fail to teach anything useful
column3: their sales pitches having been totally fraudulent. In some places (New York City comes to mind) it is possible to pursue the claimant in criminal court for a misdemeanor if the facts support such a private prosecution. That works well against unscrupulous landlords. (There is also a landlord & tenant court (Housing Court) in NYC but a tenant can be whipsawed there by lawyers acting for the landlord.)
