column2: 15:59	"    The OP posited (I think) not being resident
column3: ordinarily resident or domiciled in Britain
column4: and not visiting there except for brief meetings.

column1: There is virtually no situation where a person becomes taxable in another jurisdiction without having a permanent establishment or spending ""substantial"" time there -- artistes and sportsmen aside. It is true that active selling (advertising
column2: trade show attendance...) can be equated to permanent establishment. But this is most often the case with respect to sales tax in the USA
column3: not income tax. And for the USA there is also the principle of taxation based on nationality.

column1: The Huckaby principle (a telecommuter subjected to income tax by the State of New York based on 25% of his working time spent there)   might be kept in mind
column2: but has limited relevance in the UK-Swiss context.

column1: The tax treaty provides reassurance but really changes nothing.
The VAT issue is something else. New rules came into force on 1 January. For commercial endusers
column2: UK VAT applies; for private endusers the supplier's VAT does. But Switzerland is outside the EU and double taxation is conceivable although in practice few encounter it.

column1: Personal services companies have been under tax attack in the UK for some years now. Google ""IR35"". This won't affect you if you have no permanent establishment there.
Finally
column2: if you do not have
column3: and are unlikely to get
column4: 30 years' state pension contributions
column5: you might consider Class III voluntary contributions. Unlike Switzerland
column6: the UK allows voluntary contributions even if you are resident in the EU/EEA/Switzerland. While state pension benefits are stingy

MariVI'm also planning to do the same what you said. My understanding:
There are 2 trends at the moment:
1. The Frank is getting stronger after the National Bank stopped its interventions and nervous investors around the world change their cash to Frank as an ""escape"".
2. The Euro is getting weaker due to government debt fears across EU.

These two trends are partially independent and make the Frank stronger against all other currencies and make the Euro weaker agains all other currencies. Both of these push the CHF/EUR rate to the same direction.

The easy answer is that the best time to exchange your money is when these trends are close to end. If you want to catch the best exchange rate I suggest to wait and keep an eye on the news. Once you start hearing good news about financial markets around the world
column2: probably that will be the best time to transfer your money to Euro.

column2: 18:11	"    There is no ""American"" law
column3: any more than there is a ""United Kingdom"" law of inheritance. There are state and territory laws (and there are English
column4: Scottish
column5: N.I.
column6: Jersey
column7: etc. laws).

column1: In the USA a spouse can ""take against the Will""
column2: which means that s/he can elect to take (say) 1/2 or 1/3 of the Estate
column3: depending on whether there are offspring.

column1: In US jurisdictions the existence of a spouse and/or children excludes any right of a more distant relative to inherit in intestacy (absence of a Will).
In some US jurisdictions
column2: notably California
column3: the high expense of probate leads to a prevalence of inter-vivos trusts (revocable living trusts); in others (New York
column4: Florida)
column5: probate is cheap.

column1: In England (but apparently not Scotland   )
column2: unlike US states (spousal rights
column3: above)
column4: there is almost total freedom of testation and one can disinherit any relative and leave one's estate outside the family. But see Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975 which prevents a testator from leaving his dependents in poverty. In Louisiana
column5: alone among US states
column6: one must provide for dependent (minors under 23 and disabled) offspring
column7: but since 1989 forced heirship has been eliminated as a right for adult offspring.

column1: The rules are different in Community Property States (borrowing from Wikipedia: ""Alaska
column2: Arizona
column3: California
column4: Idaho
column5: Louisiana
column6: Nevada
column7: New Mexico
column8: Texas
column9: Washington and Wisconsin. Puerto Rico allows property to be owned as community property also as do several Indian jurisdictions. Alaska is an opt-in community property state; property is separate property unless both parties agree to make it community property through a community property agreement or a community property trust."") Actually Wisconsin is a Uniform Marital Property Act state
column10: slightly different from CP.

column1: As for Swiss law ""forcing"" inheritance upon ascendants and siblings: there are ways around that
column2: notably an ""accord successoral"" or a repudiation of inheritance by the ""forced heir"". And clever use of foreign entities and trusts (See Lambert
column3: Ian
column4: ""Using Cayman Islands Trusts to Overcome the Forced Heirship Problem ""
column5: 4 Trust L. & Practice
column7: pp. 20-24 -- although the Caron v. Odell case in France that I cited earlier suggests that any property left in Switzerland (or France
column8: etc.) could be reallocated by the courts to make up for the succession assets ""lost"" by the strategy.) New York State law specifically allows a non-domiciliary
column9: including a foreigner
column10: to elect by Will to have New York law apply: Spudis
column11: Barbara C.
column12: ""Avoiding Civil Law Forced Heirship By Stipulating That New York Law Governs ""
column13: 20 Va. J. Int'l L.

column2: 02:37	"    Ideally your employer would offer a tax equalisation scheme so that you pay the same tax that you would have paid had you remained at home
column3: your employer picking up the difference (or
column4: often
column5: collecting and keeping any savings). Normally this would be accompanied by an employer-paid accountant to prepare the real and the fictive tax returns.

column1: Assuming that you don't benefit from such a scheme
column2: how you proceed will depend on your spouse's situation and your combined offshore assets. As has been said previously these will not be taxed directly
column3: but their existence will put you into a higher tax bracket.

column1: Unless you undertake some gymnastics (separation
column2: ring-fencing assets with an entity or trust) -- and if not bona fide these put you at risk for penalties -- you face the common problem of cross-border incompatibility of tax systems and inadequate protection by tax treaties. With the changes in non-dom and non-resident taxation of a couple of years ago
column3: and the counting of days of travel and the 90-days rule
column4: being dual resident (UK & Switzerland) is a real risk. You will get a credit for tax paid to the ""other"" country
column5: but you will always pay the highest rate and (often) lose exemptions (think of ISAs
column6: etc.; and perhaps Third Pillar savings and even Children's Trust Funds).

column1: One area of incompatibility is that in the UK there is separate taxation and in Switzerland there is taxation of the family unit
column2: modified as stated above where the income and assets are attributable to a foreign-based spouse
column3: or consist of foreign real estate.

column2: 10:43	"    The page you cite may reflect the law
column3: but not entirely the practice. For example
column4: shipment of household effects from abroad to set up a second (holiday) home is free of tax for goods owned for six months (but Customs rarely makes an issue of that). A couple of years ago my removals firm got me a VAT zero-rating (that's better than an ""exemption"") on brand-new goods and their customs broker got those goods entered into Switzerland VAT-free. What's more
column5: the UK VAT zero-rating was outside the strict rules too: it was an ""indirect export""   because I selected and paid for the transporter
column6: and hence in principle unavailable to a UK resident. (See ¶3.4) But the same mover has just assured me he does this all the time
column7: with full disclosure and no objection from HMRC.

column1: So: you won't know for sure how Swiss Customs will react until you try
column2: and there is room for discretion in the wording of the page you cited. I've re-read it in Swiss languages because unofficial translations often leave something out; this one omits the time-shift issue in every version:   If you are using a single shipper for all the goods
column3: ask them. And think about the VAT issue if you are shipping
column4: say
column5: from the UK. In that case the department store (John Lewis
column6: for example; we have used them) should ship directly to the transporter. It's still and ""indirect export"" but as I said
column7: it works.

column1: Tourist VAT refunds are not so attractive as zero-rated exports since the service company takes 5-6% out of the 17-1/2% VAT refund.

column1: I'll disagree with Andy02 & Kevlegs a bit - I don't find anything in the Instructions that force you to choose between the ""resident"" or ""physical presence"" test to claim the exclusion.  The advantage of claiming both is that
column2: if the IRS wishes to challenge your claim
column3: they must challenge both tests.

column1: However
column2: from your description (and I'm   going by what you wrote) it is not clear you qualify for either.

column1: The ""bona fide resident"" test ""involves your intention...about your stay.""  Do you intend to stay in CH for an indefinite period
column2: or were you sent there by your employer for a specified (or for a limited) period?  If the latter
column3: you don't qualify.

column1: The ""physical presence"" test requires that you are outside of the US for 330 full days in the tax year.  (You need to be able to document that).  If you can
column2: you're clear
column3: but the burden of record-keeping is on you.

column1: Last
column2: but not least
column3: if you are on a salary
column4: then of course you were earning an income while on vacation.  (You would have received a paycheck for that period of time.)

column1: None of the above is meant to be discouraging
column2: but only to emphasize you should read the form's instructions very carefully.

column2: 17:53	"    Depending on your bank you may be able to finesse the issue as I did
column3: in the reverse. We bank with HSBC in London. They gave me an ABA code and a SWIFT code to use for their New York clearing office; this code has to be accompanied by the codes for our London account (SWIFT code
column4: sort code
column5: account number
column6: name of recipient). The transfer then becomes a domestic US transfer
column7: cheaper for me. They charge little or nothing for the transatlantic move from their New York clearing office to my London branch.

column1: Occasionally transfers are refused (typically with no refund of fees) because of an anomaly in the codes. The way around that is to present a fax from the destination bank
column2: on their letterhead
column3: giving the proper information. It's then impossible for the foreign bank to say it's wrong.

column1: Another solution I've used in the past is to get hold of the country desk officer (in this case the person responsible for US business) at the bank's main office and explain the problem. He or she will normally sort it out very fast. This happened to me years ago when a branch manager of Citibank refused to open a letter of credit in favour of a Korean supplier.

The difference is to ""accidental Americans"" and permanent expatriates who have no US dollar assets.

column1: Counseling such persons involves analysing whether they are genuinely free of actual or potential US assets and rights
column2: and whether they are in the line of inheritance from or to a US person. Careless planning means that Stiftung or Anstalten assets can be 100% consumed by tax very easily.

column2: the tax on Filipino expats was abolished in 1999. It made no sense to keep a tax where everybody was (out of financial necessity) cheating.

column2: 08:44	"    This is where the big mistake occurred.

column1: You knew you had no income.
But the authorities did not
column2: as you never told them via the proper channels (tax return). So the authorities made the assumption everything carried on unchanged - why should they assume otherwise?

column1: And when you didn't file on time
column2: the processes kicked in and the system started working. End result: tax department chasing you.      IMMEDIATELY
column3: if not sooner
column4: send the tax authorities a letter stating what the situation was.

column1: Enclose PROOF of your termination of employment at the end of 2008.
Enclose PROOF of your wealth (for the wealth tax) as at 31.12.2008 and as at 31.1.2009. Here on EF we have no idea if you are a pauper or a multi-millionaire
column2: so wealth tax may or may not be inconsequential

column1: Enclose PROOF that you left the country and were de-registered.
You must accept that you will have to pay tax for January 2009
column2: because you were here. At the very least: 1/12 of the wealth tax for your wealth.

column1: When I arrived in Switzerland in December one year
column2: I was in the country for 13 days before the 31st December turned around.

column1: I had no income and few assets.
I was still
column2: correctly
column3: issued a tax return
column4: which I promptly filed.

column1: It had lots of 0's in it :-)
I received a lovely letter from the tax dept
column2: properly calculating my portion of federal and wealth tax
column3: and apportioning it for the 13 days I was here.

column1: But the tax office generously let me of the CHF 1.80 tax bill :-)
So anyway
column2: TALK to the tax office straight away (or via email / letter). Explain you did not understand
column3: and fill in a tax form for them

column1: That will be likely to be very simple with no income (unless you have a complex wealth structure across many countries...)
Good luck!

column1: My rental apartment is taxed under the French system called Micro Bic. This requires for me to list the amount of net earnings from the apartment and the tax form will take about 50% removed and then tax on the balance of the 50%. This first 50% considers this paying for your mortgages
column2: taxes
column3: costs
column4: etc.. This system is used within the French Impot Declaration. In your case you will be taxed differently. I can almost say it will be more dear.

column1: If you plan on renting the apartment all furnished
column2: it's somewhat better. You can get people out of the apartment
column3: if things go pearshaped. If the apartment is empty
column4: your bail will be normally for three years
column5: six years
column6: or longer. It's tough to get the rentors out too easily.

column1: I use an agency for my apartment rental during the high season periods. This is costly but it sure is better. You have them taking all of the big part of rental apartments. My agent costs me 33% of the gross amount. Cheaper agencies will cost less but they do less too.
I hope that this gives you a bit of information. For second property in France
column2: this will take about 15 years before you sell the place without paying capital gains. For the first five years
column3: it's taxed on all capital gains. From the six to the fifteenth year it reduces each year at 10% of the cap.gains. You can still make money with the apartment
column4: if you don't turn this off in the first fifteen years.

Hi
The tax rate variation is sensitive for the income tax rate. Though as you describe the business
column2: the company seems to be eligible for a special tax status
column3: like mix or domiciled company (difference may be significant due to potential amendment of the pure domicile company with the third corporate tax reform). Thus
column4: with this status (to be submitted in written to the tax authority)
column5: the effective tax rate will be reduced to approx. 9% in Zug (even 8% with a pure domicile company
column6: but as said...). This effective tax rate won't be much different in other cantons
column7: even in the high tax cantons
column8: as for instance it will be around 11-13% in VD/GE.

column1: Thus
column2: this answers your first question: if you domicile a company at a location
column3: it's better to have the company being effectively managed from this location
column4: as in CH
column5: a company is taxable where its effective place of management is located and not where it's registered. Therefore if you intend to have employee in CH in another canton (which first means that it won't be a pure domicile company...)
column6: you should better have the company registered in that canton.

column1: Second
column2: the non distributed profits (=retained earnings) and share capital plus any legal reserves will be subject to the equity tax (capital tax) at the end of the year. The rate may vary from one canton to the other
column3: but domiciled/mixed company are taxed at a lower rate and that shouldn't be significant apart if you have hundreds of millions of retained earnings... In VD for instance
column4: the capital tax rate for a mixed company is at 0.02%...

column1: Edit: do you want to open a branch or a subsidiary? A branch may not be eligible for a special tax status
column2: this have to be discussed with the tax authority. Furthermore
column3: if it is a subsidiary of a US entity
column4: you should pay severe attention to the US rules
column5: in particular to the ""check the box"" rules to make sure you use the tax planning appropriately. You should also seriously consider the questions around repatriation of cash through dividends
column6: what's the final tax at source on dividends
column7: do you have credit on that
column8: etc. Depending what the home country is
column9: pay also attention to potential CFC rules...

4839	Financebankingtaxation	Wealth  tax on foreign business	tamash1	3315	11	Location: zug	09.11.2009
Ok
column2: so now with figures:

column1: Case 1:
assumptions: Swiss assets CHF 500'000; foreign (movable/non fixed) assets CHF 700'000; resident of Switzerland in ZH.
Taxation: you are fully subject to taxes on your worldwide income and wealth. Taxable on CHF 1'200'000 at the rate of 0.10% (as computed by kiwi).
Case 2:
Assumptions: Swiss assets CHF 500'000; foreign fixed assets (such as property) CHF 700'000; resident of CH in ZH.
Taxation: you are fully subject to taxes on your worldwide income and wealth
column2: but fixed assets located abroad are exempted from Swiss taxation
column3: but not for the tax rate. Therefore
column4: taxable in CH are CHF 500'000 at the rate of 0.10% (applicable rate for CHF 1'200'000).

column1: Case 3:
Assumptions: Swiss fixed assets CHF 500'000 (property); foreign assets CHF 700'000; resident abroad.
Taxation: you are subject to limited taxation in CH for the property only. Taxable on CHF 500'000 at the rate of 0.10% (applicable rate for CHF 1'200'000). Nevertheless
column2: in some cantons
column3: you don't have to disclose your worldwide wealth to determine the applicable rate (such as Vaud) and in most of the cantons the rate is determined by estimation. The law says that your are taxable in CH at the rate that is applicable to - at least - your Swiss income/wealth.

column1: nb: final remark for Case 1 & 2
column2: there are some limited jurisdictions that levy a wealth tax on national non fixed assets held (such as shares in a corporation) which could lead to a potential double taxation except if a double tax treaty is applicable.

column2: 06:08	"    You can withdraw funds from any foreign account up to the day limit of your account and of the particular ATM
column3: whichever is smaller (although multiple withdrawals get 'round the latter limit).

column1: However
column2: almost all banks impose a loading charge on use of cards abroad
column3: even if the withdrawal is in dollars. Except where the ATM is treated as 'domestic' (some
column4: not all
column5: ATMs on US military bases). The loading charge is at least 1% (the amount imposed by VISA and MasterCard after some litigation over excessive exchange commissions). But most banks charge more: for debit cards up to 3%. USAA Savings Bank and many credit unions charge only the 1%. American Express charges 2.7% on all foreign currency transactions
column6: plus a fee on withdrawals from your account. You have to sign up for the service; the only advantage these days is that their card is sometimes honored where a bank's own card is not.

column1: Cash withdrawals for credit card accounts involve different layers of fees plus interest.

UK debit cards from the major banks tend to impose a fixed fee plus a percentage load. But Nationwide Building Society has no fee within the EU/EEA/Switzerland (there is 1% load elsewhere -- check their Web site).
ATMs are all over the place in Switzerland. With a foreign card you can use most all of them; with a domestic card usually only the one issued by your bank or one with a special arrangement.

In principle

column1: In the absence of the word ""only"" the State of residence can also tax the income
column2: giving credit for tax paid to the State where the property is located. Compare the provisions in the US treaty for pensions:

column2: pensions and other similar remuneration beneficially derived by a resident of a Contracting State in consideration of past employment shall be taxable only in that State.

column1: (Also essentially identical in the two treaties)

column3: if any

A standard is 80% of the purchase price.
The other 20% is handled dependent on Banking policies.
Fixes last from 2-10 years.
For the remaining 20% a combination of the following can lead to a ""in all but name"" 100% loan (personally I achieved 97% exactly 2 years ago with 3% cash from the ZKB).
Therefore the other 20% can be a combination of:
1. cash
2. pillar 2 pledging or cashout
3. pillar 3 pledging or cashout
4. other securities/assets in Switzerland
Some banks have a policy of the 20% being cash or a minimum of 50k in cash.
The pros and cons of all these options have been debated on another thread. Search for details.

5027	Financebankingtaxation	Negotiation Corporation Tax Rate	Cashboy	3236	7	Location: Ticino & London	06.07.2009
making tax rate comparison with or within Switzerland is very dangerous
column2: because you first have to ensure that you compare the same thing! When comparing Swiss corporate tax rate to other countries
column3: are you sure you compare the effective tax rate? Because the tax rate you find in the tax law are the tax rate after tax (income and capital tax are tax deductible expenses in Switzerland!). For instance
column4: a holding company is subject only to federal tax (8.5%)
column5: but that rate is after tax. Therefore
column6: if you compare the effective tax rate
column7: it will be 7.83% (8.5/108.5). Same can be said to the applicable tax regime. You also need sometimes to make a distinction between the kind of income. For a holding
column8: participation income will not be taxed at all
column9: whereas other passive income (and some commercial foreign income) will be taxed at only 7.83%....

column1: You know
column2: a joke in this world is to say that Switzerland is not a tax heaven
column3: but a tax   heaven...

column2: 21:16	"    Usually
column3: the same tax officer prepares both the Federal and Cantonal assessments. Very strange if there is an inconsistency.

column1: The gross income will be the same for both. Then each Canton has its own permissible deductions. Thus the net taxable income is invariably different for Fed and canton. The Fed does not tax wealth. The Cantons do.
Moreover

There is basically 3 levels of ""evasion"" in Switzerland.
The first is named in French ""evasion fiscale""
column2: which should be translated as ""tax evasion"" in English
column3: but there is a difference to the ""real"" tax evasion (= soustraction fiscale in French) that leads into the fact of hiding or not something to the tax authority.

column1: In the lower level of tax evasion
column2: you declare everything to the tax authority but they are of the opinion that your tax planning is too agressive and abusive against law. It therefore qualifies the planning into what it should have been according to economics standards and law and you have to pay your taxes on that basis. Example: you are active in Switzerland and set up an offshore partnership and say that most of your earnings has been realized by the partnership (unilateral exemption of those earnings by Switzerland if the partnership is seen as a fix place of business (PE)). In reality
column3: you never go there and manage all your activity out of Switzerland. In your tax return you declare the partnership and its earnings. The tax authority will simply ignore the partnership and tax all the earnings of the partnership in Switzerland. There is no penalty. Some interest for late payment could be due if this is the case.

column1: In the upper level of tax evasion
column2: you hide that you have a partnership abroad and you declare only the little portion of your Swiss income. After enquiries
column3: the tax authority finds out the tax scheme and will consider this as being a ""real"" tax evasion. On top of the additional tax you have to pay
column4: you will be subject to a fine which is in an ordinary case of the same amount as the taxes you avoided. If you inform the tax authority of your evasion before it finds it out
column5: the fine is reduced up to 1/5 of the ordinary amount. Otherwise
column6: depending on the severity of your fault
column7: the fine may vary between 1/3 and 3 times the ordinary amount.

column1: The last case is what we call a ""tax fraud"". This is a tax evasion (you hide something to the tax authority) but you did it in such an ingenious manner (usually by faking official or important documents such as accounting
column2: salary certificate
column3: etc.) that it has to be qualified as a tax fraud. In addition to the fine for tax evasion
column4: there is either an additional fine (up to CHF 30'000 for federal and usually the same for cantonal taxes) or even imprisonment depending on the severity of the tax fraud...

column1: Currency markets are even less logical.  I lost track of the number of times in the 80's and early 90's that the ""experts"" felt such and such a country had a stronger economic outlook than the US and yet the currencies were inverted in their trends with each other.  Total crap.
Take the CAD and USD recently.  The CAD was at parity with the USD for the first time in 30 yrs.  People were talking about how this could go on indefinately.  Financial crisis hits
column2: and the CAD is down around 0.8 USD where it has spent the vast majority of the last 30 yrs on average (the average is perhaps just slightly lower than this).  Why?  Canada has the lowest debt to GDP ratio of the G8.  Despite promises of massive deficit spending in the next two years

5241	Financebankingtaxation	How it all started	guest	8055	132	null	null	"    With all due respect
column2: if you really believe that 'the problem started with housing' then you   understand what a mess we're in.  The roots of the crisis extend far beyond housing and bad mortgage debt alone
column3: into the very essence of the monetary system and central banking structure of the US government.

column1: At the risk of sounding like a broken record
column2: the several articles cited   will go a long way towards explaining the breadth of the problem
column3: including why advocates of the   of economic theory have been rightly predicting this present outcome for many decades.

column1: And no
column2: the government really can't do anything to fix this — the government played a large role in bringing it about. The 'bailout' being pushed on the public via Congress is not a 'fix' but a perpetuation of the same policies that caused the mess in the first place: covering massive debt by creating more debt to give the appearance of somehow paying it off.

column1: Government doesn't create value or wealth
column2: it only takes it. The illusion of creating wealth by 'creating' money is really nothing more than legalized counterfeiting
column3: in which credit is created out of thin air as the 'backing' of a new batch of freshly printed notes
column4: which are promptly circulated into the economy
column5: invariably devaluing all existing currency.  This is no less true of the proposed 'bailout' in which an eventual sum of well over the suggested $700 billion would materialize in exactly the way I just described
column6: leading to inflation as not seen in the US since the 1930s.  The ones who 'pay' for the debt thus created are invariably the public
column7: unless and until they refuse to let their government continue such practices.

column1: The only reality-based 'fix' is to face the music
column2: brace for the hardship
column3: and let the market — not the government — sort out the details.  There is no 'magic bullet' that will enable us to avoid hard times
column4: and while the 'bailout' may postpone them
column5: it will only make them harder when they do come.

My company sent me a Mercer comparison hen I transferred and indicated it was approx 13% more for the shopping basket they had chosen.
The Big Mac index reckons Switzerland is twice as expensive as Switzerland:
I reckon the reality is probably somewhere in between.
I notice the cost of meat / fish
column2: taxis
column3: eating as being the biggest difference - maybe twice as expensive here. General groceries also seem significantly more expensive. Clothes
column4: electronics
column5: white goods seem similar. Luxury European cars like Audi and BMW are much cheaper here although Ford / Opel and Japanese cars probably similar price. Petrol and diesel are more expensive (20% more?) here. Didn't use many trains or buses in Oz but trains in Switzerland are excellent and cheap with the half price card.

column1: Not sure about renting (guess Geneva is expensive?) but the one thing that seems much cheaper is a mortgage - around 3% vs 7% in Oz but you need to put down a 20% deposit.
Any maintenance - plumber
column2: sparky
column3: rennovations etc cost the earth here.

column1: But like in Sydney the great outdoors is beautiful and comes for free and Lake Geneva with the mountains in the background is a match for Sydney harbour (in my opinion...). And you get the skiing which is great value for the world class resorts you have access to.
Health Insurance is really expensive here although my few experiences with doctors/hospitals have been very good.
Although people say taxes are lower
column2: once all the deductions are taken off (AVS
column3: pension etc) there doesn't seem to be much difference in the final percentage deducted from my salary slip!

column1: Basically if you want a nice place in central Geneva
column2: buy fresh food
column3: eat and drink out regularly and get cabs you might spend 50% more than you would in Oz or more.

column1: If you live somewhere less central
column2: buy a second hand car or use the train
column3: spend your leisure time outdoors you can probably get by for 10-20% more.

column1: Switzerland is a great country though. I loved Sydney and was hesitant to leave but haven't regretted it.

5303	Financebankingtaxation	QROPS - Hope this helps...	kev330520	2139	0	Location: Zurich	26.08.2008
Hi Everyone
There seem to be alot of queries regarding QROPS on this fantastic forum so I hope that my knowledge of this will help.  I am an Offshore Financial Adviser
column2: dealt with UK pensions when an IFA in UK and deal with the QROPS schemes all the time here in Switzerland so let me try and clear a few things up.

column1: QROPS refers to the process of transferring your frozen UK pension(s) out of the UK and into an approved scheme.
They have had some bad press recently with the shut down of some schemes in Singapore and Hong Kong.  This is due to some firms 'Pension Busting'.  When you transfer a frozen UK pension
column2: there is a 5 year window in which you must reports any realisations to HMRC.  After 5 years and 1 day you can cash the pension in.  What some people have been doing is cashing the pension in within the 5 years and not reported it
column3: this has led to the closure of some schemes
column4: this is known as Pension Busting.

column1: With that in mind
column2: any QROPS scheme MUST stay for at least 5 years and is not designed to get your hands on your pension fund immediatley to buy a house etc....the few who do it might end up ruining it for the rest of us!!!  Another thing to bear in mind is the fact that this is designed for people who are not intending to return to the UK.

column1: The scheme that I recommend is set up as a trust with an offshore investment bond wrapper.  The charges for the scheme are flat rate which is why you really need to have a sizable frozen pension pot for it to work for you.
The benefits of a QROPS scheme is really the flexibility.  It means you can put all your frozen pensions into one place and have total access after 5 years.  You do not need to buy an annuity
column2: take 'x' amount as an upfront lump sum
column3: it is up to you what you do with it after the 5 years.

column1: The QROPS scheme is only an option and you should check with your Swiss company with what they offer you aswell and compare them to see which will be the best option for you.
If anyone wants more information
column2: feel free to PM or email me...

column1: I hope that this helps some way to explaining things.
Kevin

column3: they will tell you how much in taxes and customs duties you need to pay to import the bike.

column2: your tax will be adjusted in future months based on the assumption that you will continue to earn what you have earned on average so far. In addition
column3: if you've already paid more than you needed based on the new calculation
column4: then you won't have to pay so much next month. This is hard to explain
column5: but hopefully it will become clear once you see your next pay-cheque.

column1: I got a big amount paid in February
column2: and paid loads of tax on it. This month (March) I got paid my usual amount
column3: and so I paid much less tax on it than normal because the system realized that I won't continue to earn what I did in February every month this year
column4: and so I've therefore basically already paid my tax for March and April. I'm still waiting to see whether it works out entirely as I believe it should

5470	Financebankingtaxation	difference between source and income tax ?	Nessuno	2082	18	Location: Zurich	05.12.2007
I many times wondered myself what the answer would be.  In reality what you are really asking is how much tax you have to pay on your income?
Taxation at source means that you will have an estimated amount deducted from your pay.  If too much is deducted
column2: then you get a refund after you file a return/tax declaration.  Otherwise you will pay the difference between what you and what was deducted at source (from your pay).

column1: For people that do not get taxed at source (income tax is not deducted from each pay)
column2: they have to pay the entire tax due at tax return/declaration time.  However
column3: such people have to usually pay provisional taxes (called estimated taxes based on previous year income) and then pay the difference at tax return/declaration time.  Provisional taxes can be very annoying if your income varies greatly from Year to Year.

column1: Typically taxation at source (deductions from your pay) do not take into account your full situation
column2: such as allowable deductions
column3: and thus more than likely deduct too much.

column1: Best regards

column2: 20:58	"    In order to answer this question you need to create a spreadsheet to look at the effects of tax on your money
column3: which is dependent on taxable income.

column1: Effectively money invested for old age is free of tax on the capital and the interest. This is a potentially a large saving and is risk free. Any investment that you are making that has a compounded return of 8-9% or more on capital invested is not free of risk and involves securities. So on one side of the equation is your capital free of tax and with tax free interest around the 2.5%-4% and on the other is your tax liable investments on which taxable interest of say 10% is achievable with a risk factor x that could result in a loss of y%.
In other words how risk averse are you?

column3: the tax authority does not ask for any supporting documents. You can just declare the value and the tax authority usually accept your estimation.

column1: The estimation does not have to be adjusted to the changes in the exchange rate.
Foreign taxes may not be credited against the Swiss taxes. However
column2: please note that your foreign house is only taken into account in your tax declaration for the determination of the tax rate. You do
column3: therefore
column4: not pay any Swiss taxes on your foreign house.

column1: Whether you end up paying somewhat more
column2: roughly the same
column3: or somewhat less is very much dependant on your individual situation - both in Switzerland and the US.

column1: Broadly speaking
column2: and very much simplified
column3: first you pay your Swiss taxes. Then you figure out what the IRS thinks you owe them - from your income
column4: if you meet the overseas residence qualifications
column5: you may deduct the USD 82
column6: 000-ish allowance. (Or portion thereof
column7: blah blah blah...) Then you can take credit for most
column8: but not necessarily all
column9: of the taxes you paid to CH. Typically
column10: if your Swiss payments are lower than your US tax liability
column11: you will still owe Uncle Sam some dosh. If your Swiss payments were higher than your US tax liability
column12: you can carry the credits forward (I think for 5 years?) against future US taxes.

column1: There are umpteen billion pages of IRS rules
column2: regulations and formulas to wade through to figure all this out. Do consider getting professional advise.

column1: (Are you here on assignment from a US company? If so
column2: many offer tax advise
column3: and some offer tax equalization programs as part of a relocation package...)

column1: Bear in mind that the two systems think about income and deductions differently
column2: making tax/investment planning a bit trickier. Oh
column3: and taking the allowance and foreign tax credits pushes many expats into the AMT who might not otherwise be affected if resident in the US...

column1: As to why the difference in taxes across cantons and towns in Switzerland:
Essentially
column2: each canton and community decides how much revenue it needs to keep things running another year;  the tax rate is roughly based on what it will take to generate that sum
column3: given the population and wealth of the community/canton. The cool thing about Switzerland is that citizens get to vote to approve or reject the proposed rate.

column2: 00:31	"    It all depends... Generally you are able to work for 3 months on assignment without any deductions. If you are staying longer than that it depends on the type of your stay. If you fly in Monday leave Friday and are working on a contract through a non-Swiss company assignment ie it just happens to be in Switzerland then for the length of your stay you are free from all deductions. If however you are resident here then you are liable to deductions but first after 90 days. Note if you exceed the 90 days then these deductions are backdated to your entry point. The point at which tax is leviable follows the same route. IF you are in the country for more than 180 days excluding days in which you travel to and from your home then you are again liable. Hence if you are here Monday - Friday travelling in on Monday and leaving again on Friday you are exempt.

column1: But Tax and social contributions are coupled with a work permit. IF you have a work permit then you will be Taxed and liable to social contributions irrespective of length of stay. Note work permits have a general minimum length of 4 months.

5755	Financebankingtaxation	To save in funds	whoop123	1648	4	Location: SG	01.02.2007

All the 'retirement funds' in switzerland that give you tax breaks (Pillar 3a they are called) have very limited funds options from government regulation - each bank normally has their 4 choices allong the lines of conservative-dynamic with a more stock:bond ratio in each...they are all pretty dismal performers compared to the open market.
So what you want is a normal investment account and 2-300/month is definitely low in most bank eyes.  Credit Suisse has a huge stable of funds
column2: including all the ones from the non-in house firms (and everything available in English)
column3: but stock funds have a 2% buying commision with a minimum of 50Fr
column4: so at 300Fr a pop it is distressing and if you like to switch funds every month you would by Mr. credit Suisse a nice little chalet...

column1: Kantonal Bank has funds more directed to 'real' people in that you can invest 100+fr at a regular rate and not be hit so badly.  But everything is in german.
Post finance might really be the option because they seem to have info in English on their website
column2: but I have no experience with them...

Just for your information and of course if you have any questions I will provide an answer:

The EU is currently investigating Switzerland for providing state assistance to companies coming to Switzerland. There is a basic EU law which restricts and sometimes prohibits the help a government can give a company. Switzerland has a three tier tax system which allows a Gemeinde and Canton to discount tax for businesses and people for that matter and the Cantons of Schwyz and Zug are famous for doing this. The EU is of the opinion that this systems provides companies moving to Switzerland instead of being domiciled in the EU with an unfair advantage... Switzerland of course disputes this as the bilateral agreement was related to the transfer of people and not of businesses and certainly not a harmonisation of laws and taxes as implied by this EU investigation.

Recently also the Canton Zurich agreed to maintain its Cantonal 100% tax level. This has serious implications for those who will be living in Zurich in 2007 and paying tax there... Any Canton can write a small loss but larger ones based on their GDP are only allowed to occur for two consecutive years. Thereafter the Canton is obliged to bring its tax to a level where it will break even. This is a problem for Canton Zurich as the tax will need to increase by double digit % to say 115% further the Gemeindes will need to increase the tax too and business in Zurich will become less attractive. Now obviously there must be an alternative and this can be for example increasing revenue from some other source (speeding cameras
column2: and parking tickets for example!) or reducing the expenditure (closing schools for example). All in all though 2007 will be a tough year...
